Credit Hours: Prerequisite: ECGR 3101  or ECGR 3111  Cross-listed Course: ECGR 5105

Name: ECGR 4106 - Real-Time Machine Learning
Subject: ECGR
Description: An interactive practical introduction to real-time machine learning and deep learning inference based on leveraging GPU and CPU platforms.  Introduces Convolutional Neural Networks  and Recurrent Neural Networks  inference algorithms for real-time computer vision and scene analysis, including object detection, pose estimation, and activity recognition.  Examines basic deep learning constructs based on current design tools . Credit Hours: Prerequisite: ECGR 3101  or ECGR 3111  Cross-listed Course: ECGR 5106

Name: ECGR 4111 - Control Systems Theory I
Subject: ECGR
Description: The fundamentals of modern multi-input-multi-output control systems and preliminary analysis of nonlinear systems via the method of linearization.  Time domain analysis of control systems.  Design of state-feedback controller via the method of pole-placements.  Determining controllability and observability of linear systems.  The design and compensation of control systems, Phase lead, lag controller synthesis, Nyquist Stability criterion and frequency domain responses.  Credit will not be given for ECGR 4111 where credit has been given for ECGR 5411.

Name: ECGR 4112 - Principles of Digital Control Systems
Subject: ECGR
Description: Introduction to digital control system principles.  Topics include: z-transform, Laplace transform, and starred transform analysis, pulse transfer functions, digital lag, digital lead, and digital PID controller design, closed-loop stability of digital control systems, and introduction to state-variable methods.

Name: ECGR 4115 - Convex Optimization and AI Applications
Subject: ECGR
Description: Focuses on the theory and the algorithmic aspects of convex optimization. Topics include: convex sets, convex functions, and convex optimization problems; duality theory and optimality conditions; algorithms for solving convex problems; use of numerical tools to solve problems; and, if time permits, non-convex optimization problems.  Also  discussed are applications of the materials to engineering topics such as signal processing, control, robotics, machine learning, statistics, and related engineering problems.
Restrictions: Junior standing or permission of instructor

Name: ECGR 4116 - Artificial Intelligence for Biomedical Applications
Subject: ECGR
Description: Introduction to fundamental concepts of Artificial Intelligence  and its application to biomedical domain. Exposure to pattern recognition, medical image processing, algorithms and machine learning frameworks using Python.

Name: ECGR 4117 - AI for Robotics and Automation
Subject: ECGR
Description: The objective of this course is to provide students with a working knowledge of foundational theory, algorithms and design used for creating autonomous robotic systems. The course also provides students an understanding of how foundational algorithms in this area can be translated from a formal algorithmic implementation to a Deep Learning  or Artificial Intelligence  implementation. Credit will not be given for ECGR 4117 where credit has been given for ECGR 5117.

Name: ECGR 4121 - Antennas
Subject: ECGR
Description: Radiation into free space, the point source, thin linear antenna, arrays of linear elements, aperture antennas, impedance, methods of feeding, matching and termination. Antenna systems.

Name: ECGR 4122 - Acoustics
Subject: ECGR
Description: Vibrations and simple vibrating systems; radiating systems; plane waves of sound, dynamic analogies, microphones and other acoustic transducers; acoustic measurements.

Name: ECGR 4123 - Analog and Digital Communication
Subject: ECGR
Description: Analysis and transmission of signals, including analog communication systems ; digital communications systems .

Name: ECGR 4124 - Digital Signal Processing
Subject: ECGR
Description: Sampling and signal recovery in linear systems; analysis of sampled systems; discrete and fast Fourier transforms; z-transform; discrete convolution; design of digital FIR and IIR filters.

Name: ECGR 4125 - Foundation of Optical Engineering
Subject: ECGR
Description: The engineering aspects and applications of modern optics, optical communications, optical materials, optical devices, basic optical fiber and integrated optics, optical signals, and optical modulation, multiplexing, and related networks, basic Fourier optics and its application in optical images and information. Credit will not be given for ECGR 5125 where credit has been given for ECGR 4125 .

Name: ECGR 4127 - Machine Learning for the Internet of Things
Subject: ECGR
Description: Introduces the concepts and skills necessary to design, train, and deploy machine learning models in resource-constrained devices.  Topics include: analysis of the computational requirements of machine learning models; requirements of edge-deployed machine learning; techniques to reduce storage, computation, and latency; and software tools available.  The concepts are applied through a series of projects.

Name: ECGR 4131 - Linear Integrated Electronics
Subject: ECGR
Description: Design of linear integrated circuits utilizing bipolar and MOS devices. Application in linear amplifier design, control, and processing of analog signals.

Name: ECGR 4132 - Analog Integrated Circuits Design
Subject: ECGR
Description: Topics include: analog MOS modeling, design of current mirrors, references, and operational amplifiers. Both hand analysis and SPICE simulation utilized.

Name: ECGR 4134 - Solid State and Semiconductor Microelectronics II
Subject: ECGR
Description: PN-junctions and Schottky junctions; bipolar and field effect transistors; optoelectronic and heterojunction devices; lithography and integrated circuits; microwave devices; light emitting devices and detectors; quantum devices using superlattices; quantum wells and quantum dots; material preparation and characterization; and measurement techniques.

Name: ECGR 4136 - Semiconductor Optoelectronic Materials and Devices
Subject: ECGR
Description: Direct and indirect bandgap materials; Compound and wide bandgap semiconductors; Electronic properties; Optical properties; Generation and recombination; Junction theory; Light emitting devices; Optical detectors.

Name: ECGR 4138 - Electronic Thin Film Materials and Devices
Subject: ECGR
Description: Applications of thin films in microelectronics/optoelectronics manufacturing processes; vacuum technology, deposition techniques, and the characterization methods relevant to optoelectronic applications; thin film applications such as metallization, silicide formation, light emitting diodes  and lasers, and doping of semiconductors.

Name: ECGR 4141 - Power System Analysis I
Subject: ECGR
Description: Representation of power system components for analysis studies. Transmission line parameters. Network equations. Load flow analysis and numerical methods.

Name: ECGR 4142 - Power System Analysis II
Subject: ECGR
Description: Economic operation of power systems. Short circuit studies. Symmetrical components. Transient stability analysis.

Name: ECGR 4143 - Electrical Machinery
Subject: ECGR
Description: Advanced theory of transformers and rotating. Machines; harmonic and saturation effects on machine performance. Unbalanced operation and transient conditions.

Name: ECGR 4144 - Power Electronics I
Subject: ECGR
Description: High power solid state circuits. Topics include: power transfer, DC/DC converters, DC/AC inverters, AC/DC rectifiers, gate-drive circuits for linear and switching amplifiers, pulse-width modulators, power semiconductors, control and converter modeling, renewable energy system integration.

Name: ECGR 4146 - Introduction to VHDL
Subject: ECGR
Description: Introduction to VHSIC Hardware Description Language  including VHDL-based high-level design of microelectronic systems, VHDL programming, and VHDL synthesis; emphasis on learning and using industry-standard VHDL tools.
Restrictions: Engineering major or minor; and knowledge of a computer language or permission of department.

Name: ECGR 4151 - Solar Cell Fundamentals and Technology
Subject: ECGR
Description: Principles of operation and basic design features of silicon solar cells.  Clean room protocols, processes, and fabrication techniques. Solar cell fabrication, testing, and process modifications to improve performance.

Name: ECGR 4161 - Introduction to Robotics
Subject: ECGR
Description: Modeling of industrial robots including homogeneous transformations, kinematics, velocities, static forces, dynamics, computer animation of dynamic models, motion trajectory planning, and introduction to vision, sensors, and actuators.
Restrictions: Senior standing and Engineering major or minor.

Name: ECGR 4171 - Introduction to Energy Systems
Subject: ECGR
Description: Overview of energy systems: energy types, generation, conversion, storage, transportation/transmission, and utilization.  Principles, physical structure, processes, and utilization of fossil fuel, nuclear, and renewables for transportation, thermal, and electrical energy generation are discussed along with associated performance metrics.  The course also provides an introduction to environmental impacts of energy production, life-cycle analysis, energy efficiency concepts and metrics, transmission systems, grid reliability, and the impact of smart grid technologies.  All topics are presented in the context of industry standards as well as federal and state regulations.

Name: ECGR 4172 - Energy Markets
Subject: ECGR
Description: Energy and power systems in regulated and competitive environments and implications on business decisions for firms in these industries.  Topics include: mechanism of energy markets; comparative market systems; determination of prices under different market structures; gas, oil, coal, and electricity market architecture; electricity market design; dispatch and new build decisions; smart grid and renewable energy in electricity markets; risk and risk management in energy including demand and price volatility and use of financial derivatives; and the impact of financial market trends and current and proposed policies on the energy industry.

Name: ECGR 4181 - Computer Architecture
Subject: ECGR
Description: Latest research and development in the area of computer architecture; multiprocessor architecture, multi-computers, interconnection networks, branch prediction, instruction-level, data-level and thread-level parallelism, and memory hierarchy; high-performance machines and special purpose processors.

Name: ECGR 4182 - Digital System Testing
Subject: ECGR
Description: Introduction to VLSI testing, test process and automatic test equipment, test economics and product quality, test economics, fault modeling, logic and fault simulation, testability measures, combinational and sequential circuit test generation, memory test, analog test, delay test, IDDQ test, design for testability, built-in self test, boundary scan, analog test bus, system test and core test.

Name: ECGR 4185 - Advanced Electromagnetic Field Theory
Subject: ECGR
Description: Maxwell’s equations and propagation. Properties of guided and surface waves. Wave properties of light; physical and fiber optics.

Name: ECGR 4186 - Optical Communication and Optical Signals
Subject: ECGR
Description: The course covers the fundamentals of modern optical networks, optical systems, and protocols. These include transmission, detection, multiplexing/demultiplexing and related prevailing technology.

Name: ECGR 4187 - Data Communications and Networking II
Subject: ECGR
Description: Principles of data communication networks; computer communications network architecture  with emphasis on the network layer, transport layer, and application layer; local area networks; medium access control; routing; data transport; Internet applications.

Name: ECGR 4189 - Cloud Native Application Architecture
Subject: ECGR
Description: Comprehensive introduction to architecting modern applications in the cloud that scale to millions of users. The course places equal emphasis on the basic principles of the different components and practices of cloud native architectures, and hands-on experience with industry standard tools.

Name: ECGR 4190 - Power Generation: Operation and Control
Subject: ECGR
Description: Characteristics of power generation units, steam, nuclear reactor and hydroelectric. Economic and thermal system dispatch. Transmission losses, load flow problems. Hydro scheduling, hydro-plant models. Energy production cost models. Interchange evaluation.

Name: ECGR 4191 - Dynamic and Transient Analysis of Power Systems
Subject: ECGR
Description: Large-scale systems state descriptions and hierarchical control. State space models, dynamic stability and testing. Stability of simple and multi-machine systems. Transient phenomena in electrical power systems. Transient stability problem.

Name: ECGR 4231 - Sensors & Actuators
Subject: ECGR
Description: Fundamentals of sensors and actuators, and their applications in smart machines, industry, metrology, and the environment. Materials for sensors, actuators, electronic and optical sensors, electroptics, magnetooptics, and fiber optics sensors, microsensors and actuators, sensors and actuators, signal processing and interfaces.

Name: ECGR 4241 - Electrical Engineering Senior Design I
Subject: ECGR
Description: A project-oriented course stressing the planning and design of experiments to support the student’s project.  Formation of the design problem and specification.  Credit will not be given for ECGR 4241 where credit has been given for ECGR 4251 .
Restrictions: Senior standing and Electrical Engineering major.

Name: ECGR 4242 - Electrical Engineering Senior Design II
Subject: ECGR
Description: A continuation of ECGR 4241 consisting of project development and analysis, culminating in written and oral presentations.  Credit will not be given for ECGR 4242 where credit has been given for ECGR 4252 .

Name: ECGR 4251 - Computer Engineering Senior Design I
Subject: ECGR
Description: A project-oriented course stressing the planning and design of experiments to support the student’s project.  Formation of the design problem and specification.  Credit will not be given for ECGR 4251 where credit has been given for ECGR 4241 .
Restrictions: Senior standing and Computer Engineering major.

Name: ECGR 4252 - Computer Engineering Senior Design II
Subject: ECGR
Description: A continuation of ECGR 4251 consisting of project development and analysis, culminating in written and oral presentations.  Credit will not be given for ECGR 4252 where credit has been given for ECGR 4242 .

Name: ECGR 4261 - Microwave Circuit Design I
Subject: ECGR
Description: Design and analysis of microwave devices and circuits; Telegrapher’s and wave equations; physical transmission lines; circuit analysis techniques; impedance matching techniques; and Wilkinson power dividers, hybrid couplers, transformers, and filters.

Name: ECGR 4265 - Microwave Devices and Electronics
Subject: ECGR
Description: Microwave transmission line theory, parameters, microwave waveguides, microstrip line and components including resonators, slow-wave structures, tees, rings, couplers, circulators, isolators, and microwave tubes. Microwave solid state electronics, including microwave transistors, tunnel diodes, transferred electron devices, avalanche transittime devices, and mono-lattice microwave integrated circuits.

Name: ECGR 4290 - Science and Technology of Photovoltaics
Subject: ECGR
Description: Review of semiconductor properties; junctions and operating principles of solar cells; efficiency limits and losses in solar cells; solar cells and sunlight; fabrication of solar cell and modules; design of high efficiency silicon solar cells; heterojunction, thin film, and other promising solar cells; and photovoltaic systems and applications.

Name: ECGR 4311 - Digital Audio Workstations
Subject: ECGR
Description: Students learn to use Digital Audio Workstation  software for music and other audio data. Topics include: recording and importing audio and MIDI data, basic editing and mixing, effects processing, and mastering. Some audio hardware concepts are also introduced, including compression, equalization, microphones, mixers, and studio monitors.

Name: ECGR 4312 - Electronic Music Synthesis
Subject: ECGR
Description: The basics of electronic music synthesis using both software and hardware, analog and digital controllers, voltage controlled oscillators , envelope generators, voltage controlled filters , and low frequency oscillators .  A variety of techniques are covered, including modular, subtractive, and additive synthesis, and effects such as tremolo and vibrato.

Name: ECGR 4422 - Random Processes and Optimum Filtering
Subject: ECGR
Description: Review of probability, univariate and multivariate distribution functions; random processes, discrete and continuous time processes, widesense stationary, ergodicity; timeand frequency-domain analysis; linear systems, optimum filtering, Wiener filters, Kalman filters; application.

Name: ECGR 4433 - VLSI Systems Design
Subject: ECGR
Description: Analysis, design, and synthesis of very large scale integrated circuits. A project-oriented course relying heavily on computeraided design tools for logic, layout design, and simulation.

Name: ECGR 4892 - Individualized Study
Subject: ECGR
Description: Individual investigation and exposition of results.

Name: ELET 1102 - C Programming
Subject: ELET
Description: An introduction to the C programming language with an emphasis on applications in Electrical Engineering Technology.

Name: ELET 1211 - DC Circuits
Subject: ELET
Description: An introduction to electric circuits with an emphasis on DC circuit analysis and design. Topics include: fundamental electrical and magnetic principles, circuit analysis laws and theorems, and component characteristics and behaviors.

Name: ELET 1231 - Digital Circuits
Subject: ELET
Description: Fundamental digital concepts including number systems, logic gates, Boolean algebra, Karnaugh Maps, and combinational logic. Topics include: combinational digital circuit design and analysis, minimization methods, and hardware descriptor languages such as VHDL.

Name: ELET 1231L - Digital Circuits Laboratory
Subject: ELET
Description: This laboratory course supports concepts and practices covered in ELET 1231 .

Name: ELET 2112 - AC Circuits
Subject: ELET
Description: The continuation of an introduction to electric circuits with an emphasis on AC circuit analysis and design. Topics include: application of electrical and magnetic principles, analysis laws and theorems in AC circuits, an introduction to frequency response and circuit behaviors under AC excitation.

Name: ELET 2113L - DC/AC Circuits Laboratory
Subject: ELET
Description: This laboratory course supports concepts and practices covered in ELET 1211 and ELET 2112 .

Name: ELET 2221 - Electronics I
Subject: ELET
Description: An introduction to semiconductor electronic devices and circuits. Topics include: semiconductor diodes, bipolar junction transistors , field-effect transistors , ideal operational amplifiers and the application of these solid state devices in basic circuits and systems.

Name: ELET 2221L - Electronics I Laboratory
Subject: ELET
Description: This laboratory course supports concepts and practices covered in ELET 2221 .

Name: ELET 2231 - Microprocessor Fundamentals
Subject: ELET
Description: Application and design assembly and C language programming for AVR microprocessors. Topics include: system timing, bus cycles, interrupts, stacks and subroutines. Upon completion, students should be able to design, program, verify, analyze, and troubleshoot AVR assembly and C language programs.

Name: ELET 2241 - Instrumentation and Controls
Subject: ELET
Description: An introduction to instrumentation for measurement and control of physical variables, with an emphasis on electronic systems. Topics include: a review of basic circuit analysis, electrical instruments, sensors and measurement principles and a survey of automatic controls from a systems point of view.

Name: ELET 2241L - Instrumentation Laboratory
Subject: ELET
Description: This laboratory course supports concepts and practices covered in ELET 2241 .

Name: ELET 2290 - Sophomore Practicum
Subject: ELET
Description: Introduction to the design process and project management techniques with an emphasis on Engineering Technology applications.  Projects are completed individually and provide reinforcement of the design process introduced in ETGR 1101 , along with an introduction to project management techniques and technical communication in written and oral formats.  Laboratory prototypes are developed and tested. Selected project require a formal presentation.

Name: ELET 3113 - Network Analysis
Subject: ELET
Description: An introduction to frequency domain analysis through Laplace Transforms and Fourier Analysis. Topics include: a review of circuit analysis fundamentals in the time domain, circuit transformations, waveform analysis and synthesis and first order natural and forced response with extensive utilization of circuit simulation software.

Name: ELET 3132 - Digital Systems
Subject: ELET
Description: The design and implementation of digital systems. Topics include: combinational and sequential digital circuits, minimization methods, state machine design and state assignment techniques, hardware descriptor languages such as VHDL, circuit implementation using MSI integrated circuits and programmable logic devices.

Name: ELET 3132L - Digital Systems Laboratory
Subject: ELET
Description: This laboratory course supports concepts and practices covered in ELET 3132 .

Name: ELET 3141 - Power Systems and Machines
Subject: ELET
Description: An introduction to electromagnetic fundamentals, power generation and distribution, AC and DC machines.

Name: ELET 3190 - Junior Practicum
Subject: ELET
Description: Focused on an open-ended, but defined, project that is completed in a team environment. Introduces, or reinforces, group project dynamics, a formal design process, project management, information dissemination in both written and oral forms; as well as project analysis, modeling, fabrication and demonstration.  Provides the foundation for tools necessary to develop and implement a capstone project in Senior Design I and Senior Design II.

Name: ELET 3222 - Electronics II
Subject: ELET
Description: A continuation of the study of solid state devices begun in ELET 2221 . Topics include: frequency response of single and multistage amplifiers, feedback and stability, linear and nonlinear operational amplifier circuits, and CMOS and BiCMOS circuits with extensive utilization of circuit simulation software.

Name: ELET 3222L - Electronics II Laboratory
Subject: ELET
Description: This laboratory course supports concepts and practices covered in ELET 3222 .

Name: ELET 3232 - Advanced Microcontroller Systems
Subject: ELET
Description: The application and design of ARM  systems. Topics include: assembly and C language programming and an introduction to the control and interfacing of ARM based systems. Upon completion, students should be able to design, construct, program, verify, analyze and troubleshoot ARM assembly and C language programs and supporting hardware.

Name: ELET 3242 - Fundamentals of Control Systems
Subject: ELET
Description: Automatic control systems concepts, system modeling, control system components, state space model, transfer function model, time responses, poles and zeros, closed loop, reduction of multiple subsystems, stability analysis, Routh-Hurwitz, performance analysis, design techniques, root locus, Bode, Nyquist, PID, and MATLAB control tool box.

Name: ELET 4123 - Active Filters
Subject: ELET
Description: The design, analysis, simulation and implementation of composite, cascaded and summation filters. Topics include: bilinear transfer functions; cascade design with first-order circuits; biquad circuits; Butterworth lowpass circuits; Butterworth bandpass circuits; the Chebyshev response; sensitivity; frequency transformations; highpass and band-elimination filters.

Name: ELET 4133 - Embedded Systems
Subject: ELET
Description: The external characteristics of digital and analog integrated circuits and their applications when interfaced to embedded digital systems. Design constraints and considerations due to device limitations and device selection based upon application requirements will be discussed. Upon completion, students should be able to design, program, verify, analyze, and troubleshoot hardware and software in embedded systems.

Name: ELET 4142 - Power Electronics
Subject: ELET
Description: An introduction to power electronic devices in electrical systems, including their characteristics, operation, and application.

Name: ELET 4243 - Power Networks
Subject: ELET
Description: Study and design of electric power transmission and distribution systems. Topics include: power network components design and interconnection, system studies, national grid and microgrid power distribution, and grid monitoring and control.

Name: ETEL 2101 - Circuit Fundamentals
Subject: ETEL
Description: In this foundation course students will learn the principles of DC and AC circuits. Topics of study include basic components, laws, and methods used in circuit analysis. Concepts of DC and AC voltage, current and power will be explored. Students will be instructed on the correct and safe use of equipment and computer tools used in circuits testing and troubleshooting.

Name: ETEL 2161 - Foundations of Mechanics
Subject: ETEL
Description: Many engineering applications require knowledge and use of electrical and mechanical devices working together in products and systems.This course provides essential tools and a pathway to understanding of basic mechanical design principles. Students learn fundamentals of statics, dynamics, and operation of basic mechanisms. Basic properties of materials and their uses in the manufacturing of products are studied.

Name: ETEL 2171 - Algorithms and Programming
Subject: ETEL
Description: An introduction to the design and implementation of algorithms with a focus on practical problem-solving skills relevant to engineering and science. Students will learn programming techniques that are applicable to contemporary programming languages, including procedural programming, object-oriented programming concepts, data types and structures, use of libraries, and memory management. Participants will practice conceptualization, design, writing, compiling, running, testing, and debugging programs.

Name: ETEL 2181 - Circuits in Action
Subject: ETEL
Description: An introductory lab course designed to build a strong foundation in lab safety and hands-on skills. Circuit testing/troubleshooting methodologies are introduced using state-of-the-art equipment. Students build and operate functional circuits and simple systems to explore technologies and their possible applications.
Restrictions: Engineering major or minor, or permission of department

Name: ETEL 2201 - Circuit Analysis
Subject: ETEL
Description: Knowledge of DC and AC circuit analysis techniques is exercised and expanded. Students learn concepts and uses of transient signals and phasors, passive filters, voltage and current sources, as well as gain an understanding of active and reactive power. Computer-aided circuit simulation software is used throughout the course.

Name: ETEL 2271 - Digital Fundamentals
Subject: ETEL
Description: An introduction to basic logic functions and methodologies relating to digital electronics. Students learn digital signal representation, logic gates, Boolean algebra, and fundamental memory structures. These concepts are applied in the development of complex digital systems. Signal communication, encoding, and multiplexing are explored.

Name: ETEL 2281 - Doing and Making
Subject: ETEL
Description: Students are given an opportunity to devise and build working prototype solutions to elementary and intriguing challenges. Participants use basic mechanical and electrical prototyping techniques to construct and test electromechanical components. Projects include the interaction of microcontrollers and peripheral devices such as sensors and actuators.

Name: ETEL 2291 - Practical System Design
Subject: ETEL
Description: A bridging of electrical and mechanical systems knowledge and practical application. Students learn how to apply knowledge of system design under practical constraints and external requirements imposed by standards, codes and safety regulations. Participants will use modern engineering design methodologies to assure appropriate and safe interfacing of products within operational environments while ensuring the well-being of people.

Name: ETEL 3101 - Principles of Control
Subject: ETEL
Description: Provides students with essential knowledge to characterize and analyze linear time-invariant systems in both time and frequency domains. System modeling methodologies  are applied to electromechanical systems establishing the foundation needed for understanding of control and automation.

Name: ETEL 3131 - Electromechanical Devices
Subject: ETEL
Description: Comprehensive study of input and output devices, their selection, and functional design of systems. Participants will examine sensors, actuators, signals and methods used to build electromechanical devices capable of acquisition, generation, and processing of signals according to the project specifications and requirements. Students will learn how the applied design, simulation, and validate of electrical and mechanical devices used in electromechanical systems.

Name: ETEL 3171 - Digital Devices
Subject: ETEL
Description: Students study modern microcontrollers and use them to interact with peripheral devices via analog, digital, and serial communication interfaces. Participants become familiar with interrupts, timers, direct memory access, signal conversion methodologies, and other related concepts. Development of algorithms is applied to create intelligent embedded systems.

Name: ETEL 3181 - Exploring Devices
Subject: ETEL
Description: Students expand their knowledge and abilities to work with modern devices and tools by exploring multi-device projects. Various devices and their interactions with each other and human operators are explored. Students also study the functionality of Programmable Logic Controllers  and how they are used in automated industrial and manufacturing operations.

Name: ETEL 3191 - From Concept to Product
Subject: ETEL
Description: This course provides students with the knowledge and techniques essential to formulate and carry out engineering projects. Participants learn methods used for product development within the scope of the engineering design process. The course will provide tools and methods needed to execute team projects from creative ideas to ready-to-manufacture products.

Name: ETEL 3231 - Power, Machines, and Energy
Subject: ETEL
Description: Energy and power are an essential part of modern life. Students learn the fundamental concepts of power generation, transmission and distribution, including modern and emerging renewable energy sources and storage. Course participants study motors, energy flow, fluid mechanics, and their applications and practical implementation in commercial processes.

Name: ETEL 3261 - Applied Control Systems
Subject: ETEL
Description: Students learn the principles and techniques fundamental to automated control systems. Feedback control, concepts of stability, compensation, gain and phase margins, and state-space description of physical systems are studied. Concepts for designing controllers and optimizing performance of systems are explored. Modern engineering tools, including computer simulation, are used to design, verify, and evaluate stability and performance of these systems.

Name: ETEL 3271 - Digital Signals
Subject: ETEL
Description: Digital signals are important for modern technologies involving high performance data exchange, treatment, and use. In this course, students study and practice methods used in digital signal processing, including sampling and reconstruction, discrete time Fourier and Z transforms, and digital filter design.

Name: ETEL 4000 - Special Topics
Subject: ETEL
Description: Examination of specific new areas which are emerging in the various fields of electrical engineering technology. Coursework builds upon the knowledge the students have gained from their electrical engineering technology curriculum.
Restrictions: Senior standing and Electrical Engineering Technology major, or permission of department.

Name: ETEL 4131 - Intelligent Industrial Systems
Subject: ETEL
Description: Analysis and applied design of intelligent industrial systems including power converters, fluid circuits, and complex electromechanical assemblies. Participants develop an understanding of integrated power electronics, pneumatics, and fluid handling topologies and gain an ability to design advanced systems for industrial and commercial needs. Students learn how to convert electricity in order to energize and control power flow to systems.

Name: ETEL 4141 - Digital Manufacturing Methods
Subject: ETEL
Description: A study of modern advanced manufacturing methods including investigation of materials, processes, and methods.
Restrictions: Engineering major or minor; Senior standing or permission from department.

Name: ETEL 4161 - Elements of Automation
Subject: ETEL
Description: Study of the principles, building blocks and interaction of industrial components in automated and robotic systems. Students investigate system controllers and their interaction with components such as industrial sensors, actuators, motors, interfaces, controllers, communication tools, and protocols applicable to industrial automated operations.

Name: ETEL 4261 - Robotics and Cyber-Physical Systems
Subject: ETEL
Description: Investigation of how components are integrated into cyber-physical systems and discovery of how their principles apply to business and industry. Exploration of equipment integration, applications of industrial autonomous systems, life-cycle management, and wide-area control. Study of complex systems, including the implementation and control of autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

Name: ETEL 4600 - Technology Seminar
Subject: ETEL
Description: A forum for conversations and professional knowledge exchange and dissemination. Covers a broad spectrum of technologies used in smart grids, renewable energy, robotics, control systems, as well as trends and challenges related to electrical and electromechanical systems. Focus is given to current and emerging applications in the sciences, engineering, and everyday life.
Restrictions: Senior standing and Electrical Engineering Technology major, or permission of department.

Name: ETEL 4800 - Independent Study
Subject: ETEL
Description: Individual investigation and exposition of results for a directed project in electrical engineering technology.
Restrictions: Senior standing and Electrical Engineering Technology major, or permission of department.

Name: ELED 3111 - Instructional Design and Assessment in Elementary Education
Subject: ELED
Description: The study of the development of curriculum and instructional design with a focus on developing teaching techniques to increase student performance.  Candidates are introduced to standards and resources of elementary school curriculum and assessment, and they create, implement, and assess instructional segments developed using curriculum standards and student performance.

Name: ELED 3120 - The Elementary School Child
Subject: ELED
Description: Child development theories and research findings, conceptual relationships between education and developmental paradigms, pathways of individual student development, child-centered and other types of educational reforms, the concept of developmental “needs” and the roles and responsibilities of school staff for meeting children’s developmental needs. Includes approximately 10 hours of field activities.

Name: ELED 3221 - Teaching Science to Elementary School Learners
Subject: ELED
Description: Teaching strategies and materials appropriate for teaching inquiry science in grades K-6 with emphasis on using science process skills and content to develop effective science learning experiences for elementary school children. Includes 10 hours of field experiences.

Name: ELED 3223 - Teaching Social Studies and Diversity
Subject: ELED
Description: Instructional methods for teaching and integrating social studies, economics, history, civics, geography, and diversity in elementary schools.  Focuses on problem-solving, critical thinking, and democratic citizenship with strategies for valuing people with differences in learning styles, race, class, culture, gender, and disability.

Name: ELED 3226 - Teaching Language Arts to Elementary School Learners
Subject: ELED
Description: Teaching of language arts in grades K-6, including how the study of language acquisition and growth informs and guides instructional practice. Emphasis on methods for fostering growth in speaking, listening, writing, and reading across the curriculum. Includes 10 hours of field experiences.

Name: ELED 3292 - Theories and Practice for Equity in Urban Education
Subject: ELED
Description: Examines ideological, cultural, and systemic structural inequities in various educational settings, including urban education.  Focuses on educational theories and practices that promote equity and social change.  Also explores socioeconomic class, race, religion, language, and gender, and personal identity.
Restrictions: Admission to Elementary Education Program and completion of all ELED coursework except 4000-level courses.

Name: ELED 3800 - Individual Study in Elementary Education
Subject: ELED
Description: Independent study under the supervision of an appropriate faculty member.

Name: ELED 4121 - Assessment and Instructional Differentiation in the Elementary School Classroom
Subject: ELED
Description: Addresses advanced concepts for planning for K-6 classroom measurement and evaluation and the development and use of various types of classroom assessment.  Emphasis is placed on using the results of assessment to modify instruction, as well as the incorporation of best practices in differentiated instruction.  Also explores concepts and skills related to communicating student progress and various forms of technology useful for assessing student progress.

Name: ELED 4122 - Creating an Effective Environment in the Elementary School Classroom
Subject: ELED
Description: Presents research-based concepts, methods, and practices used by effective teachers in the elementary school classroom. There is an emphasis on best practices of effective classroom management and how to establish a productive classroom climate. Candidates explore methods for increasing student motivation in diverse classroom settings, building positive student-teacher relationships, proactively managing student behavior, and establishing effective parent and community partnerships.

Name: ELED 4220 - Instructional Planning for Diversity in the Elementary School Classroom
Subject: ELED
Description: Curriculum planning and development with an emphasis on relating school content and skills to designing and implementing integrated activities within a diverse elementary classroom setting.  Explores the current knowledge of best practices of a variety of teaching strategies and methods necessary to ensure equitable opportunities to all students.

Name: ELED 4255 - CAMMP: Computer Applications and Manipulative Mathematics Programs
Subject: ELED
Description: Examination of constructivism in K-8 mathematics teaching, with emphasis on concrete, representational and symbolic manipulatives; developmentally appropriate computer software.
Restrictions: Admission to Teacher Education and permission of instructor.

Name: ELED 4420 - Student Teaching/Seminar: K-6 Elementary Education
Subject: ELED
Description: Student teaching is a planned sequence of experiences in the student’s area of specialization conducted in an approved school setting under the supervision and coordination of a university supervisor and a clinical educator. During student teaching, the student must demonstrate the competencies identified for their specific teaching field in an appropriate grade level setting. The student is assigned 15 weeks in a school setting. Includes seminars. Participating students pay a course registration fee for edTPA portfolio assessment.
Restrictions: Completion of all other coursework and approved Application for Student Teaching.

Name: AEEE 4000 - Special Topics
Subject: AEEE
Description: Examination of specific new areas which are emerging in the various fields of engineering technology and/or construction management.  The course builds upon the knowledge students have gained from their engineering technology and/or construction management curriculum.
Restrictions: Senior standing, Engineering Technology or Construction Management major, or permission of department.

Name: AEEE 4140 - Energy Management
Subject: AEEE
Description: Study of the understanding and implementation of energy management techniques. Emphasis is on energy efficiency applications in homes, businesses, large buildings and industry. Topics include: energy auditing, energy management, energy cost analysis, energy & electric rate structures, lighting, HVAC systems, motors & drivers, boilers and steam systems, cogeneration, commercial and industrial applications and alternative energy sources.
Restrictions: Engineering major or minor; and a working knowledge of engineering economics and thermodynamics.

Name: AEEE 4250 - Analysis of Renewable Energy Systems
Subject: AEEE
Description: System analysis of renewable energy systems: well-to-wheels analysis, lifecycle energy and emissions, total cost, skill sets, methodologies and tool kits needed to analyze various technologies on a consistent basis for a given application. Solar photovoltaics, wind energy, and fuel cell technologies will be covered.

Name: AEEE 4275 - Building Environmental Systems
Subject: AEEE
Description: Functions and operating characteristics of the major components of refrigerating machines, heat pumps, boilers, furnaces, solar collectors, heat exchangers, fans and pumps. Emphasis on sizing, economics and performance characteristics. Includes coverage of psychometric principles and fan and pump laws.

Name: AEEE 4290 - Advanced Instrumentation
Subject: AEEE
Description: Methodologies for measurement, analysis, and control of physical components of various electromechanical systems as well as conventional and renewable energy conversion and storage systems.

Name: ENGR 0200 - Engineering FIT Program
Subject: ENGR
Description: The Engineering FIT course is designed to provide incoming first-year engineering students with the essential mathematical practices required as a strong foundation for their upcoming engineering courses. This course aims to enhance mathematical skills while offering support during the transition from high school to university life. Students will explore the practical applications of mathematics in engineering, emphasizing its significance in making a positive impact on society.
Restrictions: Be registered for the Engineering FIT program.

Name: ENGR 0600 - Engineering Freshman Learning Community Seminar
Subject: ENGR
Description: Required for all residents of the Freshman Learning Community . The FLC has three goals: build community with students, faculty, and engineering professionals; learn about the engineering disciplines; and learn how to be a successful engineering student. The seminar offers workshops, site visits, and other activities.

Name: ENGR 1100 - Engineering Pathways
Subject: ENGR
Description: Assists students in exploring the engineering disciplines offered at UNC Charlotte, learning about career opportunities, and performing a critical analysis of their career goals.  Academic and professional skills required to be successful in the College of Engineering are introduced. Students are exposed to campus resources, college culture, and student and professional organizations.

Name: ENGR 1101 - First-Year Engineering Track to Success
Subject: ENGR
Description: This course focuses on developing successful learning behaviors and major exploration. It is designed to assist with the intellectual and social transition from high school to college by increasing the involvement of students in the intellectual life of the campus; providing an orientation to resources available to students; and promoting problem solving and writing skills. May not be repeated for grade replacement.
Restrictions: Must be a participant in Engineering Track to Success Program.

Name: ENGR 1102 - Engineering Pathways II
Subject: ENGR
Description: Designed to assist students to continue an in-depth exploration of careers in the engineering field. A focus on critical thinking used to make engineering decisions and solve problems is discussed and practiced. Students are exposed to emerging fields in the engineering profession. This course is designed for first year engineering students.

Name: ENGR 1110 - Academic and Professional Skills
Subject: ENGR
Description: The course will use profiles of engineering, technology, science, and business professionals to give students an opportunity to identify with, evaluate, and discuss roles and opportunities in professional STEM environments. The course promotes soft skills like planning, goal- setting, communication and teamwork; with a particular emphasis on applications used in the engineering, engineering technology, construction management and other STEM majors.

Name: ENGR 1201 - Introduction to Engineering Practices and Principles I
Subject: ENGR
Description: An introduction to the different disciplines within engineering; the college’s computing system; academic, personal and professional development; teamwork; project planning; engineering design; engineering calculations; and oral and written communication skills within a multi-disciplinary format.
Restrictions: College of Engineering major; Register for MATH 1241 or higher.

Name: ENGR 1202 - Introduction to Engineering Practices and Principles II
Subject: ENGR
Description: Applications in the disciplines of Civil, Computer, Electrical, Mechanical, and Systems Engineering using tools and techniques specific to the major and discipline. Emphasis is on analytical and problem-solving skills and understanding of the profession/curriculum. Each course section is restricted to a specific engineering major discipline .

Name: ENGR 1241 - Engineering Analysis
Subject: ENGR
Description: Elementary functions, derivatives and their applications in engineering problems, introduction to definite integrals in solving engineering problems. May not be taken for credit if credit for MATH 1241 has been given.

Name: ENGR 2800 - College of Engineering Ambassadors’ Leadership Development
Subject: ENGR
Description: Course activities involve participating in training sessions and monthly meetings with the Outreach and Recruitment Committee; conducting engineering lab tours, workshops and presentations; leading and participating in college sponsored STEM activities; and supporting K-12 and community college recruitment events and the Dean and Chairs functions as needed.
Restrictions: College of Engineering major and GPA greater than 2.5; Participation is through a competitive selection process.

Name: ENGR 3095 - Leadership Academy Capstone
Subject: ENGR
Description: Participants apply leadership, teamwork, ethical decision-making, communication, and strategic planning principles learned during prior semester Leadership Academy modules to a community-based service learning project. Implementation and evaluation of projects are approved by Leadership Academy staff and advisory board members.
Restrictions: Admittance into the Leadership Academy program, and Engineering major or minor.

Name: ENGR 3210 - Senior Design Laboratory I
Subject: ENGR
Description: Laboratory experience to facilitate team interaction and mentor instruction in the multidisciplinary capstone experience.

Name: ENGR 3220 - Senior Design Laboratory II
Subject: ENGR
Description: Continuation of Senior Design I Laboratory to facilitate team interaction and mentor instruction in the multidisciplinary capstone experience.

Name: ENGR 3290 - Fundamentals of Engineering Review
Subject: ENGR
Description: Review of the basic engineering and science material covered on the Fundamentals of Engineering examination, the first step toward professional licensure.
Restrictions: Senior standing and Engineering major or minor.

Name: ENGR 3295 - Multidisciplinary Professional Development
Subject: ENGR
Description: A series of multidisciplinary and disciplinary seminars and activities designed to introduce students to basic concepts of professionalism in engineering. Topics include: global, societal, and contemporary issues of current interest such as leadership, entrepreneurship, ethics, cultural diversity, and professional licensure. Each course section is restricted to a specific engineering major discipline . Sections may be cross-listed with more than one engineering major discipline .
Restrictions: Junior or Senior standing per departmental requirements; and Engineering major or minor.

Name: ENGR 3500 - Engineering Cooperative Education Experience
Subject: ENGR
Description: This course is required of Co-op students during the semester they are working.  Participating students pay a course registration fee for transcript notation.  Assignments must be arranged and approved in advance.   The Cooperative Education Program is only open to undergraduate students; graduate level students are encouraged to contact their academic departments to inquire about academic or industrial internship options for credit.  For more information, contact the University Career Center.

Name: ENGR 3790 - Engineering Honors Seminar I
Subject: ENGR
Description: Seminar focuses on development of a proposal for the Honors Senior Design II course.  The proposal is submitted through Application to Candidacy process for approval by the Honors College.  Seminar includes presentations associated with preparing for the Engineering Honors Seminar II course.

Name: ENGR 3791 - Engineering Honors Seminar II
Subject: ENGR
Description: Students prepare and present a portfolio showing the impact of the Senior Design process on their preparation for a professional career in engineering.

Name: ENGR 4090 - Special Topics
Subject: ENGR
Description: Directed study of current topics of special interest.

Name: ETEL 3281 - More Doing and Making
Subject: ETEL
Description: Students will be challenged to apply project design processes to formulate and build complete solutions to complex engineering problems. Students collaborate to integrate components and subsystems according to engineering best practices.

Name: ETGR 1100L - Engineering Technology Computer Applications Laboratory
Subject: ETGR
Description: Introduces the use of computer applications required for engineering technologists. Topics include: using the computer to solve technical problems, an introduction to engineering computer applications, the use of standard office software, and the use of scientific calculators.

Name: ETGR 1101 - Introduction to Engineering Technology and Construction Management
Subject: ETGR
Description: An introduction to disciplines and professional skills in the engineering technology and construction management professions. Topics include: academic, personal, and professional development; teamwork; engineering design; project planning and implementation; and oral and written communication skills.

Name: ETGR 1103 - Technical Drawing I
Subject: ETGR
Description: The fundamentals of technical drawing. Topics include: drawing layouts, sketching, orthographic projections, views, lines, dimensioning techniques, and introduction to Computer Aided Drawing . Upon completion of the course, students should be able to understand, interpret, and produce basic technical drawings, as well as be familiar with the most common commands of modern computer aided drawing tools such as AutoCAD.

Name: ETGR 1104 - Technical Drawing II
Subject: ETGR
Description: A continuation of ETGR 1103 , this course introduces the student to advanced techniques of Computer-Aided Drawing .  Topics include: three-dimensional wireframe, surface, and solid models, as well as rendering and generation of two-dimensional technical drawings from three-dimensional models.  Upon completion of the course, students should be able to create, modify, and render three-dimensional models using modern computer-aided drawing tools such as AutoCAD.

Name: ETGR 1201 - Introduction to Engineering Technology
Subject: ETGR
Description: An introduction to disciplines and professional skills in the engineering technology and construction management professions. Topics include: academic, personal, and professional development; teamwork; engineering design; mathematical problem solving; and oral and written communication skills.
Restrictions: College of Engineering majors only. Permission of department required for non-majors.

Name: ETGR 2101 - Applied Mechanics I
Subject: ETGR
Description: Fundamentals and applications of statics to include the analysis of force systems using analytical and graphical methods. Included topics are systems of forces, friction, equilibrium of particles and rigid bodies, distributed force systems, centroids and moments of inertia, and introduction to analysis of structures. In addition, stress, deformation, and strain are presented.

Name: ETGR 2102 - Applied Mechanics II
Subject: ETGR
Description: Fundamentals of mechanics of deformable bodies. Topics of study include building loads, stress and strain, thermal deformation and stress, axial load, statically indeterminate axially loaded members, the principle of superposition, torsion, bending and shear stresses in and strain, Mohr’s circle, and stability and buckling of columns.

Name: ETGR 2106 - Electronic Circuits and Devices
Subject: ETGR
Description: Provides an introduction to AC and DC circuits. Simple series and series-parallel circuits are used to illustrate applications of Ohm’s Law and Kirchhoff’s Laws. Power in DC resistive circuits are discussed. Sine waves, complex numbers and phasors are introduced to show their applications to analysis of AC circuits. Capacitors and inductors and their effects are covered.

Name: ETGR 2230 - Occupational Safety
Subject: ETGR
Description: An overview of occupational safety which introduces the numerous safety issues commonly found throughout the world.  Topics include: ergonomics, industrial hygiene, accident causation, hazardous materials, health- and safety-related organizations, code compliance, and national standards that address health and safety.
Restrictions: Sophomore standing or permission of department

Name: ETGR 2272 - Engineering Analysis II
Subject: ETGR
Description: A continuation of the study of engineering problem-solving procedures utilizing integral calculus. Topics include: integration, areas, volumes, centroids and moments of inertia by integration and multivariate calculus to include partial derivatives, and double integration.

Name: ETGR 3000 - Special Topics in Engineering Technology
Subject: ETGR
Description: Examination of specific new areas which are emerging in the various fields of engineering technology. The course builds upon the knowledge the students have gained from their engineering technology curriculum.
Restrictions: Senior standing and Engineering Technology major, or permission of department.

Name: ETGR 3171 - Engineering Analysis III
Subject: ETGR
Description: A continuation of engineering analysis which includes additional topics and applications in differential equations and linear algebra.

Name: ETGR 3222 - Engineering Economics
Subject: ETGR
Description: Principles of evaluating alternative engineering proposals. Compound interest formulas and applications, present worth, equivalent uniform annual value, rate of return, depreciation and depletion, economic feasibility of projects.

Name: ETGR 3295 - Multidisciplinary Professional Development
Subject: ETGR
Description: A series of multidisciplinary and disciplinary seminars and activities designed to introduce students to basic concepts of professionalism in engineering. Topics include: global, societal, and contemporary issues of current interest such as leadership, entrepreneurship, ethics, cultural diversity, and professional licensure. Each course section is restricted to major disciplines in engineering technology . Sections may be cross-listed with more than one engineering major discipline .
Restrictions: Junior or Senior standing, and Engineering major or minor.

Name: ETGR 3695 - Engineering Technology Practicum Seminar
Subject: ETGR
Description: Required during the semester immediately following each work assignment for students enrolled in ENGR 3500 ; for presentation of engineering reports  on work done the prior semester.

Name: ETGR 4100 - Capstone Design Project I
Subject: ETGR
Description: First of a two-semester course sequence in which student teams implement a Senior-level design project which demonstrates abilities as developed by the coursework taken thus far.  Project planning techniques are utilized to make substantial progress toward implementation of a design solution.
Restrictions: Engineering major or minor; Senior standing; and completion of all lower-division courses and deficiencies.

Name: ETGR 4200 - Capstone Design Project II
Subject: ETGR
Description: Second of a two-semester course sequence in which student teams continue to implement a Senior-level design project which demonstrates abilities as developed by the coursework taken thus far. The design solution developed in the first semester is completed and evaluated during the second semester. The primary engineering results delivered is a set of rational decisions, where the rationality of those decisions are supported by the appropriate analysis and testing. The quality of the design is usually reflected in a prototype of either the hardware or software system.

Name: ETGR 4272 - Engineering Analysis IV
Subject: ETGR
Description: A continuation of engineering analysis to include additional topics and applications in vector operations, probability, and statistics.

Name: ETGR 4301 - Environmental Pollution Control
Subject: ETGR
Description: The major aspects of preventing and controlling air, water, and solid-waste pollution and disposal.  Topics include: environmental standards and regulations, engineering controls, remediation techniques, sampling and monitoring, and environmental toxicology.
Restrictions: Engineering major or minor, and Junior or Senior standing in the department

Name: ETGR 4302 - Industrial Hygiene
Subject: ETGR
Description: Introduces the industrial hygienist’s role in characterizing chemical, physical, and biological hazards in the workplace.  Topics include: occupational standards and regulations, indoor air quality, ionizing and non-ionizing radiation, thermal stress, sampling/monitoring techniques, personal protective equipment, engineering controls, and program management.
Restrictions: Engineering major or minor, and Junior or Senior standing in the department

Name: ETGR 4303 - Applied Ergonomics and Human Factors
Subject: ETGR
Description: An overview of the physiological, biomechanical, and psychological concepts related to workplace layout, machine tools, and work methods.  An emphasis is placed on the control and prevention of injuries from over-exertion and related musculoskeletal disorders.
Restrictions: Engineering major or minor, and Junior or Senior standing in the department

Name: ETGR 4305 - System Safety Design and Management
Subject: ETGR
Description: Application of the techniques and concepts of system safety methodologies and process safety management.  Emphasis on the application of scientific, design, and management principles incorporating safety audits, safety management, risk assessment, loss control, and statistical applications across all phases of a system life cycle.

Name: ETME 2141 - Applied Engineering Materials
Subject: ETME
Description: An introduction to structure, properties, and applications of metallic, plastic, ceramic and composite materials. Material treatments and testing of properties will also be discussed.

Name: ENGL 1201 - English Learning Community
Subject: ENGL
Description: A continuation of the English Learning Community’s First-Year Seminar course which provides time to meet with faculty and English student organizations, as well as maintain the student community through the duration of the first-year experience.

Name: ENGL 1502 - Global Arts/Humanities: Global Connections in English Studies
Subject: ENGL
Description: Introduction to a range of oral, written, printed, visual, and/or digital texts from global communities and cultures, paying attention especially to language, diverse perspectives, modes of creation, and/or pedagogical approaches.

Name: ENGL 1512 - Local Arts/Humanities: Local Connections in English Studies
Subject: ENGL
Description: Introduction to a range of oral, written, printed, visual, and/or digital texts from local communities and cultures, paying attention especially to language, diverse perspectives, modes of creation, and/or pedagogical approaches.

Name: ENGL 2015 - Topics in Writing
Subject: ENGL
Description: Offers instruction and practice in special types of writing, such as writing for publication , which are not included in other writing courses. In addition, some sections may offer instruction in various aspects of effective writing. Not more than three hours of 2015 may be used toward the requirements for the English major . The maximum hours of credit allowed for any student are six for ENGL 2015 .

Name: ENGL 2050 - Topics in English
Subject: ENGL
Description: Designed to offer topics of general interest not included in other courses.

Name: Writing Intensive
Subject: ENGL
Description: Designed to offer topics of general interest not included in other courses. Fulfills General Education writing goal.

Name: ENGL 2072 - Topics in Literature and Film
Subject: ENGL
Description: Critical study of the intersections of literature and film.

Name: ENGL 2074 - Topics in Children’s Literature, Media, and Culture
Subject: ENGL
Description: Study of children’s literature as it relates to other media for young people, including film, television, digital narratives, games, and/or comics.

Name: ENGL 2081 - Topics in Author, Pop Culture, and Genre Studies
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in author, pop culture, and genre studies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

Name: ENGL 2082 - Topics in Film, Performance, and Print & Digital Culture
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in film, performance, and print and digital culture.

Name: ENGL 2083 - Topics in Genders, Sexualities, and Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in genders, sexualities, and literature.

Name: ENGL 2084 - Topics in Global Cultures, Identities, and Diverse Literatures
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in global cultures, identities, and diverse literatures.

Name: ENGL 2085 - Topics in Literature, Science, and the Environment
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in literature, science, and the environment.

Name: ENGL 2090 - Topics in English
Subject: ENGL
Description: Special topics not included in other courses.

Name: ENGL 2100 - Writing About Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Combined practice in writing and study of literature, emphasizing writing processes, including revision.
Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Fields of Study :              Architectural History and Criticism; Child & Family Development Studies; Diverse Literatures and Cultural Studies; Elementary Education; English; Middle Grades Education; Special Education

Name: ENGL 2106 - Film Criticism
Subject: ENGL
Description: Introduction to film as an art form. Emphasis will be on the critical analysis of the form and the content of films with attention to issues of visual narrative, audience, cinematography, editing, acting, etc.

Name: ENGL 2108 - Introduction to Drama
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative plays of the western world from the classical period to the modern period to introduce students to drama as literature, with consideration of staging, conventions of the theater, types of drama, and dramatic theory.

Name: ENGL 2116 - Introduction to Technical Communication
Subject: ENGL
Description: Technical Communication theory  is taught in the context of oral and written formats, such as memoranda, proposals, reports, PowerPoint presentations, and includes formats and content common to students’ own disciplines.

Name: ENGL 2126 - Introduction to Creative Writing
Subject: ENGL
Description: Introduction to creative writing, including both poetry and fiction writing, assuming little or no previous creative writing experience.

Name: ENGL 2127 - Introduction to Poetry Writing
Subject: ENGL
Description: An introductory course for those with little experience in reading, writing, and critiquing poetry. Students read and discuss poetry in an anthology and also be responsible for writing poems based on assigned formal strategies or themes and for bringing them to a workshop setting for group critique.

Name: ENGL 2128 - Introduction to Fiction Writing
Subject: ENGL
Description: An introductory course for those with little experience in reading, writing, and critiquing fiction. Students read and discuss short stories in an anthology and also be responsible for writing stories based on assigned formal strategies or themes and bringing them to a workshop setting for group critique.

Name: ENGL 2161 - Grammar for Writing
Subject: ENGL
Description: A systematic, hands-on review of the grammar behind professional copy editing for academic and public submission, including techniques for using sentence structure, word choice, and information management to make texts intuitively appealing without sacrificing precision and to maximize reading speed.

Name: ENGL 2201 - Contemporary Poetry
Subject: ENGL
Description: Introduction to current trends in American and world poetry. Encourages creativity and scholarly engagement with the exciting and multifaceted world of contemporary poetry.

Name: ENGL 2202 - Contemporary Fiction
Subject: ENGL
Description: Introduction to current trends in contemporary fiction. Encourages creative and scholarly engagement with the world of contemporary fiction.

Name: ENGL 2301 - Introduction to African American Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Survey of the major periods, texts, and issues in African American literature.

Name: ENGL 2400 - American Literature Survey
Subject: ENGL
Description: Surveys the whole of American literature from the Colonial to the Modern period. Major authors and literary movements, as well as important ideas and cultural issues are addressed.

Name: ENGL 2401 - British Literature Survey I
Subject: ENGL
Description: Surveys British literature from the Medieval period to the Renaissance. Major authors and literary movements as well as important ideas and cultural issues are addressed.

Name: ENGL 2402 - British Literature Survey II
Subject: ENGL
Description: Surveys British literature from the Neoclassical to the Modern period. Major authors and literary movements, as well as important ideas and cultural issues are addressed.

Name: ENGL 3050 - Topics in English
Subject: ENGL
Description: Special topics not included in other courses.

Name: Writing Intensive
Subject: ENGL
Description: Special topics not included in other courses.

Name: Writing Intensive and Oral Communication
Subject: ENGL
Description: Offers topics of general interest not included in other courses.

Name: ENGL 3072 - Topics in Literature and Film
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in literature and/or film.

Name: ENGL 3074 - Topics in Children’s Literature, Media, and Culture
Subject: ENGL
Description: Study of children’s literature as it relates to other media for young people, including film, television, digital narratives, games, and/or comics.

Name: ENGL 3081 - Topics in Author, Pop Culture, and Genre Studies
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in author, pop culture, and genre studies.

Name: ENGL 3082 - Topics in Film, Performance, and Print & Digital Culture
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in film, performance, and print and digital culture.

Name: ENGL 3083 - Topics in Genders, Sexualities, and Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in genders, sexualities, and literature.

Name: ENGL 3084 - Topics in Global Cultures, Identities, and Diverse Literatures
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in global cultures, identities, and diverse literatures.

Name: ENGL 3085 - Topics in Literature, Science, and the Environment
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in literature, science, and the environment.

Name: ENGL 3102 - Literature for Young Children
Subject: ENGL
Description: Critical study of literature for children under the age of eight, covering such topics as picture books, nursery rhymes, and books for beginning readers.

Name: ENGL 3103 - Children’s Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Critical study of various genres of children’s literature, such as realistic fiction, fantasy, and picture books.

Name: ENGL 3104 - Literature for Adolescents
Subject: ENGL
Description: Critical study of literature intended for adolescent and preadolescent readers, as well as texts that deal with coming-of-age themes.

Name: ENGL 3125 - Introduction to U.S. Latinx Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Examines contemporary and recent literatures written in English in the U.S. by Latinx writers, and is designed to introduce students to the variety of texts and contexts which shape contemporary U.S. Latinx literary experiences.

Name: ENGL 3132 - Introduction to Contemporary American English
Subject: ENGL
Description: Introduction to the study of word formation, the sound system, and the structure of contemporary American English, including characteristics and applications of traditional grammar.

Name: ENGL 3158 - Gender and African American Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Exploration of the intersection of gender and African American literature, focusing on either Black women writers or Black male writers, or a combination in dialogue.

Name: ENGL 3159 - African American Poetry
Subject: ENGL
Description: Intensive study of African American poetry, focusing on one period or traversing several.

Name: ENGL 3162 - Language and the Virtual World
Subject: ENGL
Description: Explores the various ways in which language is used in cyberspace, and how those practices are re-shaping our daily lives and our cultural expectations.

Name: ENGL 3180 - Language and Digital Technology
Subject: ENGL
Description: Rhetorical, psychological, and anthropological theories that underscore the interrelations of written, graphic, and digital communication within technical, rhetorical contexts.

Name: ENGL 3190 - Teaching Academic English to Adolescent Learners
Subject: ENGL
Description: An overview of the theories, approaches, and challenges of teaching academic English in secondary school language arts settings.

Name: ENGL 3201 - Intermediate Poetry Writing
Subject: ENGL
Description: Combines reading and discussion of published poetry with the writing of original creative works.

Name: ENGL 3202 - Intermediate Fiction Writing
Subject: ENGL
Description: Combines reading and discussion of published fiction with the writing of original creative works.

Name: ENGL 3211 - Medieval Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative British literary texts  that embody the cultural and literary developments of the Medieval era.

Name: ENGL 3212 - British Renaissance Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative British literary texts  that embody the cultural and literary developments of the 16th and/or 17th centuries.

Name: ENGL 3213 - British Literature of the Restoration and 18th Century
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative British literary texts  that embody the cultural and literary developments of the Restoration and/or 18th century.

Name: ENGL 3214 - Romantic British Literature, 1785-1832
Subject: ENGL
Description: Literature from the Romantic period, with emphasis on the works of specific writers, which may include works by men and women writers such as Wordsworth, Blake, Coleridge, Wollstonecraft, Austen, and Smith.

Name: ENGL 3215 - British Victorian Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative British literary texts  that embody the cultural and literary developments of the Victorian era.

Name: ENGL 3216 - British Literature in Transition, 1870-1914
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative British literary texts  that embody the cultural and literary developments of the period 1870-1914.

Name: ENGL 3217 - Modern British Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative British literary texts  that embody the cultural and literary developments of the 20th and 21st centuries.

Name: ENGL 3231 - Early African American Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Exploration of the major periods, texts, and issues in African American literature from its origins to the Harlem Renaissance.

Name: ENGL 3233 - American Literature of the Romantic Period
Subject: ENGL
Description: Important writers and ideas of the period of American romanticism, from Irving through Whitman, including such authors as Poe, Emerson, Thoreau, Hawthorne, and Melville.

Name: ENGL 3234 - American Literature of the Realist and Naturalist Periods
Subject: ENGL
Description: Important writers and ideas of American literature, from Whitman through the period of World War I, including such authors as Dickinson, Twain, Howells, James, Crane, Dreiser, and Frost.

Name: ENGL 3235 - Modern American Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative American literary texts  that embody the cultural and literary developments of the 20th and 21st centuries.

Name: ENGL 3236 - African American Literature, Harlem Renaissance to Present
Subject: ENGL
Description: Exploration of the major periods, texts, and issues in African American literature from the Harlem Renaissance to the present.

Name: ENGL 3237 - Modern and Recent U.S. Multiethnic Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Representative U.S. multiethnic texts  exemplifying the literary and cultural developments of the 20th and 21st centuries.

Name: ENGL 3852 - Independent Study
Subject: ENGL
Description: Individual investigations and appropriate exposition of the results.

Name: ENGL 4002 - Women and Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics focusing on women and literature, such as images of women, women as writers, and women as literary critics.

Name: ENGL 4008 - Topics in Advanced Technical Communication
Subject: ENGL
Description: Exploration, both theoretically and practically, of the interrelation of written, oral, graphic, and digital communication within technical rhetorical contexts.

Name: ENGL 4050 - Topics in English
Subject: ENGL
Description: Special topics not included in other courses.

Name: Writing Intensive
Subject: ENGL
Description: Special topics not included in other courses.

Name: ENGL 4072 - Topics in Literature and Film
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in literature and/or film.

Name: ENGL 4074 - Topics in Children’s Literature, Media, and Culture
Subject: ENGL
Description: Study of children’s literature as it relates to other media for young people, including film, television, digital narratives, games, and/or comics.

Name: ENGL 4077 - Topics in Rhetoric and Composition
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in rhetoric and composition.

Name: ENGL 4081 - Topics in Author, Pop Culture, and Genre Studies
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in author, pop culture, and genre studies.

Name: ENGL 4082 - Topics in Film, Performance, and Print & Digital Culture
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in film, performance, and print and digital culture.

Name: ENGL 4083 - Topics in Genders, Sexualities, and Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in genders, sexualities, and literature.

Name: ENGL 4084 - Topics in Global Cultures, Identities, and Diverse Literatures
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in global cultures, identities, and diverse literatures.

Name: ENGL 4085 - Topics in Literature, Science, and the Environment
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected topics in literature, science, and the environment.

Name: ENGL 4102 - British Children’s Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Focuses on works in British and British Colonial Children’s literature.

Name: ENGL 4103 - American Children’s Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Focuses on works in American Children’s literature.

Name: ENGL 4104 - Multiculturalism and Children’s Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Focuses on works that represent one or more kinds of cultural, ethnic, or social diversity of the United States and other national literatures.

Name: ENGL 4111 - Ancient World Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Readings of ancient world literature, in English translation.

Name: ENGL 4112 - Modern World Literature
Subject: ENGL
Description: Readings in modern world literature, in English and in English translation.

Name: ENGL 4116 - Shakespeare’s Early Plays
Subject: ENGL
Description: A study of 10 representative plays from the comedies, histories, and tragedies written 1590-1600.

Name: ENGL 4117 - Shakespeare’s Late Plays
Subject: ENGL
Description: A study of 10 representative plays from the period 1600-1611, including the late tragedies and tragi-comedies.

Name: ENGL 4120 - Romantic British Literature, 1785-1832
Subject: ENGL
Description: Literature from the Romantic period, with emphasis on the works of specific writers, which may include works by men and women writers such as Wordsworth, Blake, Coleridge, Wollstonecraft, Austen, and Smith.

Name: ENGL 4132 - British Drama to 1642
Subject: ENGL
Description: A survey of late-medieval and Renaissance drama in England.

Name: ENGL 4141 - American Literature of the Realist and Naturalist Periods
Subject: ENGL
Description: Important writers and ideas of American literature, from Whitman through the period of World War I, including such authors as Dickinson, Twain, Howells, James, Crane, Dreiser, Frost.

Name: ENGL 4145 - Literature of the American South
Subject: ENGL
Description: Selected works of Southern writers that reflect literary and cultural concerns from Colonial times to the present, including such authors as Poe, the early humorists, local color writers, Chopin, Faulkner, Warren, O’Connor, Welty.

Name: ENGL 4151 - Drama
Subject: ENGL
Description: Drama written in English, focusing on a particular period, nationality, or topic.

Name: ENGL 4160 - Origins of Language
Subject: ENGL
Description: Study of linguistic theories of how and when human language developed, with attention to parallel work in anthropology, archeology, and psychology.

Name: ENGL 4161 - Modern English Grammar
Subject: ENGL
