Description: Explores the dimensions of creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles by examining team dynamics and historical leadership theories that form the basis of the Army leadership framework.  Students practice aspects of personal motivation and team building in the context of planning, executing, and assessing team exercises and participating in leadership labs.  Includes instruction in troop leading procedures, tactical movement, squad level operations, battle drills, and problem solving.  Participation in leadership lab is required.  There is no military obligation to take this course; open to all UNC Charlotte and CAEC consortium students.

Name: MSCI 2101L - Innovative Team Leadership Lab
Subject: MSCI
Description: Students become proficient in the basic fundamentals and are introduced to leading a small team.  This is taught through multiple venues including advanced land navigation, survival skills, building terrain models, medical skills, movement formations, movement techniques, special teams, writing operations orders, situation reporting, call for fire, and introduction to battle drills.  Sophomores focus on mentoring freshmen and serve as team leaders.

Name: MSCI 2102 - Foundations of Tactical Leadership
Subject: MSCI
Description: Examines the challenges of leading teams in the complex operational environment. The course highlights dimensions of terrain analysis, patrolling, route planning, and operations orders. Further study of the Army Leadership Requirements Model explores the dynamics of adaptive leadership in the context of military operations. There is no military obligation to take this course; open to all UNC Charlotte and CAEC consortium students. Participation in leadership lab is required.

Name: MSCI 2102L - Foundations of Tactical Leadership Lab
Subject: MSCI
Description: Students become proficient in the basic fundamentals and are introduced to leading a squad-based element.  This is taught through multiple venues including advanced land navigation, building terrain models, advanced rifle marksmanship, medical skills, movement formations, movement techniques, special teams, writing operations orders, situation reporting, call for fire, and introduction to battle drills.  Sophomores focus on mentoring freshmen and serve as team leaders.

Name: MSCI 3000 - Evolution of American Warfare
Subject: MSCI
Description: An historical overview of the American Military Experience and an understanding of military principles, strategy, and tactics since the 17th century.  Staff ride and systematic battlefield analysis exercises provide examples of the evolution of strategy, tactics, and military technology.  These examples provide a foundation for lessons in leadership that students can use in their future military career.

Name: MSCI 3101 - Adaptive Team Leadership
Subject: MSCI
Description: Academically challenging course where Cadets study, practice, and apply the fundamentals of Army leadership, Army values and ethics, personal development, and small unit tactics at the squad level.  At the conclusion of this course, cadets will be capable of planning, coordinating, navigating, motivating and leading a 9-person squad in the execution of a tactical mission during a classroom practical exercise, a leadership lab, or during a situational training exercise  in a field environment.  Successful completion of this course helps prepare cadets for success at the ROTC Cadet Leader Course  which they attend the following summer at Fort Knox, KY.  Cadets receive systematic and specific feedback on their leader attributes, values and core leader competencies from their instructor, other ROTC cadre, and MSIV Cadets who evaluate them using the ROTC leader development program  model.  Cadets will be tasked with managing the training of MS II cadets based on direction from MS IV cadets.  Course includes instruction in squad operations, problem solving, and combat orders.  Participation in leadership lab is required.

Name: MSCI 3101L - Adaptive Team Leadership Lab
Subject: MSCI
Description: Challenging scenarios related to small-unit tactical operations are used to develop self-awareness and critical thinking skills.  The cadet will receive systematic and specific feedback on leadership abilities.  Cadets at this level serve as the Non-Commissioned Officer  Corps of the ROTC Battalion; they plan, rehearse, and lead basic course cadets through the program of instruction.  Juniors are the executors of the battalion.  Cadets also work on skills that help them succeed at CLC.  Those skills include Land Navigation and Squad Level Leadership Tactics.

Name: MSCI 3102 - Applied Team Leadership
Subject: MSCI
Description: A continuation of MSCI 3101 , where Cadets study, practice, and apply the fundamentals of Army leadership, Army values and ethics, personal development, and small unit tactics at the patrol/platoon level.  At the conclusion of this course, cadets will be capable of planning, coordinating, navigating, motivating and leading a 24-person patrol in the execution of a tactical mission during a classroom practical exercise, a leadership lab, or during a situational training exercise  in a field environment.  Successful completion of this course helps prepare cadets for success at the ROTC Cadet Leader Course  which they attend the following summer at Fort Knox, KY.  Cadets receive systematic and specific feedback on your leader attributes, values and core leader competencies from their instructor, other ROTC cadre, and MSIV Cadets who evaluate them using the ROTC leader development program  model.  Course includes instruction in platoon operations, stability and support operations, and garrison orders.  Participation in leadership lab is required.

Name: MSCI 3102L - Applied Team Leadership Lab
Subject: MSCI
Description: Specific instruction is given in individual leader development, planning and execution of small-unit operations, individual and team development, and the Army as a career choice.  Prepares cadets for the mandatory 32-day Cadet Leader Course  at Fort Knox, KY, during the summer between their Junior and Senior academic years.

Name: MSCI 4101 - Developing Adaptive Leaders
Subject: MSCI
Description: Cadets explore the dynamics of leading in the complex situations of current military operations.  They examine differences in customs and courtesies, military law, principles of war, and rules of engagement in the face of international terrorism.  They also explore aspects of interacting with non-government organizations, civilians on the battlefield, the decision making processes and host nation support.  Participation in leadership lab is required.  Mandatory for all Senior ROTC cadets.

Name: MSCI 4101L - Developing Adaptive Leaders Lab
Subject: MSCI
Description: Cadets lead cadets at lower levels. Leadership experiences are designed to prepare them for their first military unit of assignment. Identify responsibilities of key staff members, coordinate staff roles amongst twelve separate universities and colleges that make up the ROTC battalion, and use battalion field/garrison situations to teach, train, and develop subordinates. Seniors are the battalion’s staff, primary supervisors and planners, preparing to transition to Second Lieutenants.

Name: MSCI 4102 - Leadership in a Complex World
Subject: MSCI
Description: Cadets identify the leaders roles and responsibilities for enforcing Army policies and programs.  Also covers how to manage Comprehensive Solider Fitness .  Cadets also explore the dynamics of building a team prepared to handle any future operational environment and win, as well as examine the importance of understanding culture and how it affects the overall mission.  Cadets develop both oral and written communication skills by conducting a battle analysis and decision briefs.  Participation in leadership lab is required.  Mandatory for all Senior ROTC cadets.

Name: MSCI 4102L - Leadership in a Complex World Lab
Subject: MSCI
Description: A continuation of responsibilities listed in MSCI 4101L . The leadership lab uses case studies, scenarios, and tactical vignettes to prepare cadets to face the complex ethical and practical demands of leading as a commissioned officer in the United States Army.

Name: MSCI 4800 - Operational Planning, Independent Study
Subject: MSCI
Description: Provides students with customized coursework specific to a doctrinal area of focus within the United States Army.  As a future Army Officer, Cadets are required to develop and refine their planning abilities; specifically, they must possess the capabilities to define mission parameters, forecast logistical requirements, anticipate contingencies, effectively delegate sub-tasks appropriately, and then supervise every phase of a given mission from planning, to execution, to completion.  Many of the intricacies of this process are unique to various functional areas throughout the United States Army.  Students are assigned theoretical mission planning exercises based on historic vignettes, which are specific to the branch or functional area for which they will be assigned , upon commissioning as an Officer in the United States Army.

Name: MDGK 1201 - Elementary Modern Greek I
Subject: MDGK
Description: Fundamentals of the Modern Greek language, including speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

Name: MDGK 1202 - Elementary Modern Greek II
Subject: MDGK
Description: Fundamentals of the Modern Greek language, including speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

Name: MUSC 1100 - Rudiments of Music
Subject: MUSC
Description: An introductory course in music literacy, including clefs, pitches, key signatures, durational values, and rests. May be taken concurrently with MUSC 1101 .

Name: MUSC 1101 - Introduction to Aural Skills and Sight-Singing
Subject: MUSC
Description: An introduction to Aural Skills and Sight- Singing , including pitch-matching, modal identification, and rhythmic dictation.  May be taken concurrently with MUSC 1100 and/or MUSC 1237 .  Three contact hours.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUSC 1102 - Fundamentals of Musicianship
Subject: MUSC
Description: An introductory course in basic musicianship, including music literacy  and aural skills .

Name: MUSC 1222 - Jazz Ensemble Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: The teaching and administration of public school jazz ensembles including rehearsal techniques, and analyzing appropriate literature and teaching materials. Fieldwork may be required.

Name: MUSC 1223 - Woodwind Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: Playing and teaching techniques and materials for flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, and saxophone.

Name: MUSC 1225 - Brass Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: Playing and teaching techniques and materials for trumpet, horn, trombone, euphonium, and tuba.

Name: MUSC 1227 - String Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: Playing and teaching techniques and materials for violin, viola, cello, and bass.  Two contact hours.

Name: MUSC 1228 - Advanced String Skills
Subject: MUSC
Description: Advanced playing and teaching techniques and materials with an emphasis on secondary string instruments. Credit Hours: Prerequisite: MUSC 1227  or permission of instructor

Name: MUSC 1229 - Percussion Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: Playing and teaching techniques and materials for snare drum, timpani, mallet percussion, and accessory instruments.

Name: MUSC 1230 - Structure and Style of Music I
Subject: MUSC
Description: The study of basic music theory, including the analysis of diatonic harmony, two-part counterpoint, and the fundamentals of part-writing.

Name: MUSC 1230L - Aural Skills and Sight-Singing I
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for MUSC 1230 . It contains the practical application of material from MUSC 1230 , as well as rhythms through simple and compound meters.

Name: MUSC 1231 - Structure and Style of Music II
Subject: MUSC
Description: The continued study of basic music theory, including harmonic sequences, phrase and period structures, binary form, and an introduction to chromatic harmony.

Name: MUSC 1231L - Aural Skills and Sight-Singing II
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for MUSC 1231 . It contains the practical application of material from MUSC 1231 , as well as rhythms through simple and compound meters with varying subdivisions.

Name: MUSC 1233 - Class Piano I
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for MUSC 1230 . Functional keyboard skills and technique in a group setting, including the harmonization, transposition, and improvisation of diatonic melodies, as well as sight-reading and repertoire.

Name: MUSC 1234 - Class Piano II
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for MUSC 1231 . The continued study of functional keyboard skills and technique, including the harmonization, transposition, and improvisation of major and minor melodies in a variety of keys, as well as sight-reading and repertoire.

Name: MUSC 1236 - Movement for Musicians
Subject: MUSC
Description: A laboratory that investigates the intellectual and physical coordination of the musician using a blended approach of various movement/coordinative modalities and developmental approaches.
Restrictions: Acceptance as Music major or minor.

Name: MUSC 1237 - Class Voice
Subject: MUSC
Description: Class instruction in voice.
Restrictions: Acceptance as Music major, minor, or Undergraduate Certificate in Musical Theatre; or permission of department.

Name: MUSC 1238 - Guitar Class I
Subject: MUSC
Description: Class instruction in guitar.

Name: MUSC 1239 - Guitar Class II
Subject: MUSC
Description: Continuation of MUSC 1238 .  Class instruction in guitar.

Name: MUSC 1240 - Class Voice for Musical Theatre
Subject: MUSC
Description: Class instruction in voice for Musical Theatre.
Restrictions: Music major or minor; acceptance in the Undergraduate Certificate in Musical Theatre; or permission of the department

Name: MUSC 1300 - Performance Class
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for Applied Music that provides students with the experience of participating in masterclasses and formal recitals. By also serving as audience members and assisting during public concerts, the students cultivate proper audience decorum, contribute to a professional environment for all university performances, and increase their knowledge of the repertoire from various cultures and historical periods.  Includes introductions to various issues related to health and safety.

Name: MUSC 1402 - Opera and Musical Theatre Practicum
Subject: MUSC
Description: Practical application of production work in the areas of: introductory stage rigging, lighting adjustments, supertitling, costume, props, backstage management and backstage crew for final rehearsals and performances of the Opera Workshop ensemble.

Name: MUSC 1403 - Audio Engineering Practicum
Subject: MUSC
Description: Practical application of audio engineering work in the areas of recording, controlling, editing, and distributing sound and audio for dance, music, and theatre.

Name: MUSC 1502 - Global Arts/Humanities: Music in Global Communities
Subject: MUSC
Description: All Global Theme courses explore the central, unifying question of what it means to be a citizen of the world. Through the study of one or more different peoples, societies or cultures across the globe, students will be able to better understand themselves as part of a complex, interconnected world. We approach our interdisciplinary study of music with the understanding that the social, cultural, and political contexts where music is created, shared, and heard inform the sounds of the music and its various interpretations and meanings. May not be taken for credit and for a grade if credit has been received for LBST 1103 .

Name: MUSC 1512 - Local Arts/Humanities: Music in U.S. Communities
Subject: MUSC
Description: All Local Theme courses explore the central, unifying question of what it means to be a member of the “local” community in which we live. Through the study of the experiences of different peoples, cultures, and communities in our city, our region, or our nation, students will be able to better understand themselves in the context of the complex and diverse society in which we live. In this course, we seek to understand musical practices in U.S. communities in their social context. We approach our interdisciplinary study of music with the understanding that social, cultural, and political contexts where music is created, shared, and heard inform the sounds of the music and its various interpretations and meanings.

Name: MUSC 2001 - Topics in Music
Subject: MUSC
Description: Special topic in music.

Name: MUSC 2101 - Introduction to Music Business
Subject: MUSC
Description: An overview of various aspects of the music business, including marketing, promotion, communication, conduct, organization, accounting, and administration. Course projects may include the creation of promotional materials and planning a CD/DVD recording project.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor.

Name: MUSC 2137 - Phonetics and Articulation for Singers I: Italian and Latin Diction
Subject: MUSC
Description: The teaching of the International Phonetic Alphabet  and its application to pronunciation and articulation in vocal music in Italian and Latin.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor.

Name: MUSC 2138 - Phonetics and Articulation for Singers II: English Diction
Subject: MUSC
Description: The application of the International Phonetic Alphabet  to pronunciation and articulation in vocal music in English.

Name: MUSC 2140 - Double Reed Making
Subject: MUSC
Description: Designing and adjusting American-style oboe and/or bassoon reeds, including techniques for cane selection, gouging, shaping, profiling, and sharpening the reed knife.  Two contact hours.

Name: MUSC 2150 - Accompanying for Pianists
Subject: MUSC
Description: Accompanying techniques for pianists. Required accompanying of solos by other student musicians.

Name: MUSC 2151 - Introduction to Music Technology
Subject: MUSC
Description: An introduction to the standard applications of music technology, including general computing processes, digital audio, MIDI, music notation, and computer-aided instruction.  Requirements include a project focused on music and culture outside of the classical music canon.

Name: MUSC 2191 - Incorporating Music Into the Elementary Classroom
Subject: MUSC
Description: Students develop basic music skills that will allow them to choose, prepare, and teach appropriate music materials for inclusion in the classroom curricula.  Field work required.

Name: MUSC 2222 - Marching Band Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: The organization and administration of marching band programs in school settings, the application of teaching techniques for the outdoor program and the practical use of computerized software for designing and teaching of field drills. Field-experience observations of school groups are required. Three contact hours.
Restrictions: Acceptance as Music major or minor.

Name: MUSC 2230 - Structure and Style of Music III
Subject: MUSC
Description: The study of intermediate music theory, including chromatic harmony, modulation, and simple forms.

Name: MUSC 2230L - Aural Skills and Sight-Singing III
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for MUSC 2230 . The practical application of material from MUSC 2230 , as well as cross-rhythms involving duplets and triplets.

Name: MUSC 2231 - Structure and Style of Music IV
Subject: MUSC
Description: The continued study of intermediate music theory, including advanced chromaticism, largescale forms, and an introduction to serialism and basic set theory.

Name: MUSC 2231L - Aural Skills and Sight-Singing IV
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for MUSC 2231 . The practical application of material from MUSC 2231 , as well mixed meters and advanced cross-rhythms.

Name: MUSC 2233 - Class Piano III
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for MUSC 2230 . The continued study of functional keyboard skills and technique, including chromatic harmonization, the transposition and improvisation of melodies with simple harmonic accompaniments, sight-reading, repertoire, and accompanying.

Name: MUSC 2234 - Class Piano IV
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for MUSC 2231 . The continued study of functional keyboard skills and technique, including chromatic harmonization, the transposition and improvisation of melodies with four-part accompaniments, score reading, sight-reading, repertoire, and accompanying.

Name: MUSC 2235 - Jazz Improvisation I
Subject: MUSC
Description: An introduction to jazz theory and its execution through instrumental improvisation. Detailed study of harmony, chord/scale relationships, musical forms, and the integration of this knowledge into performance. Open to instrumentalists only.

Name: MUSC 2236 - Jazz Improvisation II
Subject: MUSC
Description: A continuation of MUSC 2235 , with greater emphasis on performance and integration of advanced harmonic/melodic devices and concepts, solo transcriptions, basic piano voicings, and composition memorization. Open to instrumentalists only.

Name: MUSC 2237 - Phonetics and Articulation for Singers III: German Diction
Subject: MUSC
Description: Phonetics and articulation in vocal music in German.

Name: MUSC 2238 - Phonetics and Articulation IV: French Diction
Subject: MUSC
Description: Phonetics and articulation for singers in vocal music in French.

Name: MUSC 2240 - Introduction to Composition
Subject: MUSC
Description: Introduces fundamental principles and techniques of composition, including melody, harmonic progression, phrase construction, motive, and simple formal design.

Name: MUSC 2400 - Sophomore Review
Subject: MUSC
Description: A Sophomore-level proficiency examination consisting of a transcript evaluation, an applied performance evaluation, and an interview. See the Department of Music Student Handbook for details.

Name: MUSC 2410 - Music Internship
Subject: MUSC
Description: Provides a meaningful work experience in fields such as music business, music industry, and arts administration. Requires 40-50 hours of supervised employment per credit hour. Proposal forms must be completed and approved prior to registration.

Name: MUSC 3130 - Counterpoint
Subject: MUSC
Description: A detailed study of contrapuntal styles of the 16th and 18th centuries through extensive exploration of melodic, harmonic and rhythmic designs with an emphasis on the composition of motets, inventions, and fugues.

Name: MUSC 3134 - Fundamentals of Conducting
Subject: MUSC
Description: Conducting techniques for instrumental and choral ensembles. Field work required.

Name: MUSC 3135 - Choral Conducting
Subject: MUSC
Description: Developing conducting skills for interpreting choral music. Field work required.

Name: MUSC 3136 - Instrumental Conducting
Subject: MUSC
Description: Developing conducting skills for interpreting instrumental music. Field work required.

Name: MUSC 3150 - Advanced Accompanying for Pianists
Subject: MUSC
Description: Advanced accompanying techniques for pianists. Required accompanying of solos by other student musicians.

Name: MUSC 3151 - Accompanying for Non-Pianists
Subject: MUSC
Description: Accompanying techniques for music teachers and private studio instructors, with an emphasis on techniques appropriate for use in classrooms, rehearsals, and studios.

Name: MUSC 3170 - Music History I
Subject: MUSC
Description: The intensive study of the development of ideas and styles in the western musical tradition from Classical Antiquity through the Baroque Period.

Name: MUSC 3171 - Music History II
Subject: MUSC
Description: The intensive study of the development of ideas and styles in the western musical tradition from the Classical period to the present.

Name: MUSC 3252 - Jazz Piano Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: Develops jazz piano playing skills with blues and standard jazz harmonic progressions.  Content includes the development of common harmonic techniques in jazz compositions, and the interpretation and performance of them in standard jazz literature on the piano.

Name: MUSC 3300 - Advanced Performance Class
Subject: MUSC
Description: This is a lab course for Advanced Applied Music that provides students with multiple experiences of performing in front of an audience. By also serving as audience members and assisting during public concerts, the students continue to cultivate proper audience decorum, contribute to a professional environment for all university performances, and increase their knowledge of the repertoire from various cultures and historical periods.  Includes introductions to various issues related to health and safety.

Name: MUSC 4001 - Advanced Topics in Music
Subject: MUSC
Description: Special advanced topic in music.

Name: MUSC 4037 - Vocal Literature
Subject: MUSC
Description: A survey of American, British, French, German, and Italian literature for solo voice, including a study of style and interpretation.

Name: MUSC 4090 - Choral Ensemble Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: An introduction to the voice and to teaching choral ensembles most often found in school programs for pre-service instrumental/general music teachers. Students explore how to effectively rehearse, manage, and perform with a choral ensemble. Students also explore developmentally appropriate vocal-pedagogy concepts for adolescent through adult-aged singers.

Name: MUSC 4094 - Instrumental Ensemble Techniques
Subject: MUSC
Description: An introduction to the band and orchestra instruments most often found in school instrumental music programs for pre-service choral/general music teachers. Students explore how to effectively rehearse, manage, and perform with an instrumental ensemble. Students also explore the acoustics, sound production, and basic techniques of instruments in the brass, woodwind, string, and percussion families.

Name: MUSC 4132 - Guitar Pedagogy and Literature
Subject: MUSC
Description: A survey of teaching methods, historical and pedagogical texts, and literature for guitar.

Name: MUSC 4133 - Wind Pedagogy and Literature
Subject: MUSC
Description: A survey of teaching methods, historical and pedagogical texts, and literature for woodwind and brass instruments.

Name: MUSC 4134 - String Pedagogy and Literature
Subject: MUSC
Description: A survey of teaching methods, historical and pedagogical texts, and literature for string instruments.

Name: MUSC 4135 - Percussion Pedagogy and Literature
Subject: MUSC
Description: A survey of teaching methods, historical and pedagogical texts, and literature for percussion instruments.

Name: MUSC 4136 - Keyboard Pedagogy and Literature
Subject: MUSC
Description: A survey of teaching methods, historical and pedagogical texts, and literature for keyboard instruments.

Name: MUSC 4137 - Vocal Pedagogy
Subject: MUSC
Description: A methodology course designed to present the physiological and acoustical bases for a coherent approach to the teaching of singing. Areas of vocal technique to be studied include the physiology of the voice, posture, breathing, onset of sound, articulation, vocal registration, and other related areas.

Name: MUSC 4138 - Jazz Pedagogy and Materials
Subject: MUSC
Description: The teaching and conducting of public school instrumental and vocal jazz ensembles, including rehearsal techniques, concert presentation, the history and theory of jazz, sources for appropriate teaching materials and improvisation techniques. Field work required.

Name: MUSC 4149 - Violin Pedagogy
Subject: MUSC
Description: A methodology course outlining the teaching techniques, materials, and related literature necessary for offering private instruction on the violin.

Name: MUSC 4153 - Advanced Vocal Pedagogy
Subject: MUSC
Description: An advanced course studying the practical aspects of teaching voice, including problem-solving techniques, comparison of various teaching methods, psychology of teaching voice, age-specific teaching techniques, use of movement, and vocalize analysis.

Name: MUSC 4230 - Form and Analysis
Subject: MUSC
Description: The impact of form and process on the analysis and interpretation of music. A detailed examination of common practice forms such as Binary, Ternary, Rondo, Theme and Variation, and Sonata form.

Name: MUSC 4231 - Post-Tonal Processes
Subject: MUSC
Description: The study of contemporary music through the implementation of a variety of analytical techniques such as modal analysis, set theory, and serial analysis, including an exploration of contemporary styles including Impressionism, Modernism, Neoclassicism, Post-Serialism, Minimalism, and Neo-Romanticism.

Name: MUSC 4234 - Jazz Arranging and Composition
Subject: MUSC
Description: The study of arranging and orchestration techniques in the jazz style. Detailed analysis of historically important music scores for jazz combo and jazz ensemble. Instrument ranges, scoring techniques, and advanced harmonic substitutions are addressed. Combo and large ensemble writing projects are assigned.

Name: MUSC 4235 - Orchestration and Arranging
Subject: MUSC
Description: Orchestration and the techniques used to transcribe and arrange music for vocal and instrumental ensembles with a focus on writing and performance.

Name: MUSC 4240 - Composition
Subject: MUSC
Description: An introduction to compositional techniques of melody, harmony, rhythm, form, and instrumentation with an emphasis on writing, listening, and performance.

Name: MUSC 4241 - Advanced Composition
Subject: MUSC
Description: The advanced study of composition, including process, form, pitch and rhythmic organization, and instrumentation. The course consists of advanced private instruction, a one-hour lesson per week, focusing exclusively on the writing and performance of original compositions.

Name: MUSC 4298 - Jazz History
Subject: MUSC
Description: The study of significant musicians and literature in the history of jazz. Detailed analyses of influential scores and recordings will constitute a significant part of the course. Written projects such as research and listening reaction papers will be assigned.

Name: MUSC 4410 - Senior Music Internship
Subject: MUSC
Description: Provides a meaningful work experience in any music or music-related field. Enrollment for two credit hours requires a minimum of 50 hours of supervised employment.  Enrollment for three credit hours requires a minimum of 100 hours of supervised employment. Enrollment for four credit hours requires a minimum of 150 hours of supervised employment. Proposal forms must be completed and approved prior to registration.

Name: MUSC 4800 - Senior Project Preparation
Subject: MUSC
Description: The preparation of an independent project. Proposal forms must be completed and approved prior to registration.

Name: MUSC 4900 - Music Capstone
Subject: MUSC
Description: Completion of a Senior Music Internship or a Senior Project.

Name: MUED 2100 - Introduction to Music Education
Subject: MUED
Description: Introduction to the organization and various types/levels of music education. Overview of historical, ethical, legal, and instructional issues related to music education and diversity in the classroom. A minimum of five hours of community service is required.

Name: MUED 2200 - Foundations of Music Education
Subject: MUED
Description: Examination of the social, historical, legal, and philosophical foundations of music education, major issues in American education as they relate to music education research, classroom diversity issues, and instructional planning. Clinical experiences required.

Name: MUED 2241 - Music Development and Learning
Subject: MUED
Description: Introduction to human developmental learning theories and the psychology of music as they relate to teaching music in public schools. Topics include research based perspectives of: 1) education developmental learning theories; 2) musical learning; 3) teaching musical skills; and 4) musical roles. Clinical experiences in various levels and music education settings  required.

Name: MUED 3270 - Teaching Discipline: Assessment and Behavior in the Music Classroom
Subject: MUED
Description: Students develop specific quantitative and qualitative methods that address unique discipline, teaching, and assessment concerns inherent in a music classroom with typical and diverse populations of students. Clinical experiences observing and working with students in a low-performing school setting required.

Name: MUED 4190 - Choral Methods
Subject: MUED
Description: The development of advanced planning and rehearsal techniques, choral pedagogy, selecting and teaching developmentally appropriate diverse repertoire, and administering secondary public school choral programs.

Name: MUED 4190L - Choral Methods Lab
Subject: MUED
Description: Application of content from MUED 4190 with choral ensembles. Clinical experiences required.

Name: MUED 4192 - General Music Methods
Subject: MUED
Description: General music methods and materials for elementary grades through high school. Primarily focused on elementary school general music but extends into teaching general music and non-performance based music courses in grades 6 through 12. Topics include current school music theories, diverse song literature for teaching, and approaches to general music teaching with diverse and differently-abled learners.

Name: MUED 4192L - General Music Methods Lab
Subject: MUED
Description: Clinical application of content from MUED 4192 with an on-campus lab ensemble and through clinical hours in a K-12 school setting.

Name: MUED 4194 - Instrumental Methods
Subject: MUED
Description: Development of advanced planning and rehearsal techniques, instrumental pedagogy, selecting and teaching developmentally appropriate diverse repertoire, and administering public school instrumental music programs.

Name: MUED 4194L - Instrumental Methods Lab
Subject: MUED
Description: Clinical application of content from MUED 4194 with an on-campus lab ensemble and public school instrumental ensembles. Clinical experiences required.

Name: MUED 4467 - Student Teaching/Seminar: K-12 Music
Subject: MUED
Description: Student teaching is a planned sequence of teaching experiences in the student’s area of specialization conducted in an approved school setting under a Faculty Site Coordinator and a clinical educator. During student teaching, the student must demonstrate the competencies identified for their specific teaching field in an appropriate grade-level setting. The student is assigned 16 weeks in a school setting. Includes seminars and required professional development. Participating students pay a course registration fee for edTPA portfolio assessment.

Name: MUPF 1110 - Orchestra
Subject: MUPF
Description: An orchestral ensemble performing music from across the chamber, symphonic, choral, and operatic repertoires.  Performs standard orchestral works from the Baroque Period through the present.
Restrictions: Advanced string, wind, and percussion players from any major by audition or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1111 - Jazz Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: An ensemble specializing in performance and study of music composed for standard “big band” instrumentation. Performs music styles from the Swing era to present day.

Name: MUPF 1111L - Jazz Ensemble Sectional Rehearsals
Subject: MUPF
Description: Sectional rehearsals for MUPF 1111 .

Name: MUPF 1112 - Wind Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble open to advanced wind and percussion players from any major. Performs traditional and contemporary band literature in concerts a minimum of twice per semester. Occasional concert tours and performances for important regional music events.

Name: MUPF 1112L - Wind Ensemble Sectional Rehearsals
Subject: MUPF
Description: Sectional rehearsals for MUPF 1112 .

Name: MUPF 1113 - Symphonic Band
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble open to students from any major with experience playing wind and percussion instruments. No formal audition required, only a simple hearing to determine chair placement. Performs traditional and contemporary band literature in one concert each semester.

Name: MUPF 1114 - Basketball Band
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble for University athletic contests and other campus events.

Name: MUPF 1115 - Guitar Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble.

Name: MUPF 1117 - Instrumental Lab Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: Students meet to create a beginning band or orchestra for the purposes of rehearsing on a secondary instrument in an ensemble format.  This format also allows student conductors in instrumental conducting and methods the opportunity to rehearse and conduct a novice ensemble.  Four semesters of MUPF 1117 are required for the B.M. with Concentration in Instrumental/General Music Education .

Name: MUPF 1118 - Marching Band
Subject: MUPF
Description: Weekly rehearsals and performances at football games and other university/community events. Pre-season camp and performances outside of class are required.

Name: MUPF 1119 - Special Instrumental Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: An alternative to traditional ensembles listed above for students with specialized performance interests.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a music major and permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1120 - University Chorale
Subject: MUPF
Description: A mixed chorus that performs music of many styles from the Baroque period to the present. The enrollment ranges from 46 to 58 voices. Open to all UNC Charlotte students with extensive choral experience.

Name: MUPF 1120L - University Chorale Sectional Rehearsals
Subject: MUPF
Description: Sectional rehearsals for MUPF 1120 .

Name: MUPF 1121 - Chamber Singers
Subject: MUPF
Description: A highly-select mixed ensemble that ranges in size from 15 to 26 voices. This ensemble specializes in virtuosic literature from the Renaissance, Early Baroque, and Contemporary periods. Open to all UNC Charlotte students. A full-year commitment is expected.

Name: MUPF 1122 - Men’s Chorus (Mallard Creek Chorale)
Subject: MUPF
Description: The Mallard Creek Chorale draws upon majors from across campus and performs several times each semester, including occasionally performing off campus and at athletic events. The ensemble performs folk, spirituals, Broadway, patriotic, barbershop, du-wop, and other musical styles traditional for men’s choruses. This ensemble is open to all male UNC Charlotte students with an interest in singing. Special emphasis is placed on building vocal technique and sight singing ability.

Name: MUPF 1123 - Women’s Chorus (Charlotteans)
Subject: MUPF
Description: The Charlotteans is open to all female UNC Charlotte students with an interest in singing. This ensemble performs a vast array of music from Renaissance through contemporary composers. Emphasis is placed on building vocal technique and sight singing ability.

Name: MUPF 1124 - Opera Workshop
Subject: MUPF
Description: Performance of scenes, acts, and entire operas.

Name: MUPF 1125 - Gospel Choir
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the gospel choir repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1128 - Special Vocal Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: An alternative to the traditional ensembles listed above for students with specialized experience. Enrollment restricted to music majors.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major and permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1132 - Wind Quintet
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the wind quintet repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1134 - Flute Choir
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the flute choir repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1136 - Clarinet Choir
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the clarinet choir repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1137 - Saxophone Quartet
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the saxophone quartet repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1139 - Woodwind Chamber Music
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the woodwind chamber music repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1142 - Brass Quintet
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the brass quintet repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1143 - Trumpet Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the trumpet ensemble repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1144 - Horn Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the horn ensemble repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1146 - Tuba/Euphonium Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the tuba/euphonium repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1149 - Brass Chamber Music
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the brass chamber music repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1151 - Percussion Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the percussion ensemble repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1155 - Piano Ensemble
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the piano ensemble repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1168 - Philharmonia
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble open to string players from any major. Performs string orchestra repertoire from the Baroque period through the present. Emphasis is placed on developing techniques and sight-reading ability.

Name: MUPF 1169 - String Chamber Music
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the string chamber music repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1170 - Jazz Combo
Subject: MUPF
Description: A small performing ensemble that focuses on jazz repertoire and improvisation.

Name: MUPF 1199 - Vocal Chamber Music
Subject: MUPF
Description: A performing ensemble that focuses on the vocal chamber music repertoire.

Name: MUPF 1240 - Applied Music: Euphonium
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1241 - Applied Music: Trumpet
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1242 - Applied Music: French Horn
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1243 - Applied Music: Trombone
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1244 - Applied Music: Tuba
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1245 - Applied Music: Guitar
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1246 - Applied Music: Harp
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1247 - Applied Music: Organ
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1248 - Applied Music: Piano
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1249 - Applied Music: Violin
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1250 - Applied Music: Viola
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1251 - Applied Music: Cello
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1252 - Applied Music: Bass
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1253 - Applied Music: Voice
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1254 - Applied Music: Flute
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1255 - Applied Music: Clarinet
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1256 - Applied Music: Saxophone
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1257 - Applied Music: Oboe
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1258 - Applied Music: Bassoon
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1259 - Applied Music: Percussion
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction, a half-hour lesson per week per credit hour, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or minor, or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1260 - Applied Music: Jazz Saxophone
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction in jazz, a half-hour lesson per week, or an hour lesson every two weeks, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1261 - Applied Music: Jazz Trumpet
Subject: MUPF
Description: Private instruction in jazz, a half-hour lesson per week, or an hour lesson every two weeks, leading to a formal jury at the end of the semester.
Restrictions: Acceptance as a Music major or permission of instructor.

Name: MUPF 1262 - Applied Music: Jazz Trombone
Subject: MUPF

Name: EXER 4105 - Leadership in Healthcare Organizations
Subject: EXER
Description: Focuses on the theories and practices of leadership in healthcare. Global, social, legal, political, economic, and ethical issues are explored.

Name: NDSS 2101 - Introduction to Sleep Medicine
Subject: NDSS
Description: An introduction to sleep science by examining the history of the profession of sleep medicine, basic principles of sleep medicine practice and procedures. The current structure, limitations, political climate and future considerations for the profession are also discussed.

Name: NDSS 3101 - Pathophysiology of Sleep, Neurological, and Related Disorders
Subject: NDSS
Description: Explores the diseases affecting the nervous system, the sleep/wake cycle, and psychiatric and behavioral disorders. Topics include: etiology, clinical manifestations, pharmacology, disease prevention, and overview of treatments.

Name: NDSS 3102 - Neurological and Sleep Diagnostic and Therapeutic Methods, and Monitoring Services
Subject: NDSS
Description: Explores the services available at sleep and neurophysiology laboratories and interpretation of diagnostic findings. Topics include: sleep procedures, and electroencephalography/longterm epilepsy monitoring. Students participate in laboratory practice sessions.

Name: NDSS 3104 - Advanced Sleep and Neurodiagnostic Clinical Procedures
Subject: NDSS
Description: Explores advanced clinical procedures performed in sleep centers and neurophysiology laboratories. Topics include: patient assessment, suggested immobilization test, ambulatory EEG, actigraphy, portable monitoring, dental sleep medicine, nocturnal ventilator support, and current issues and trends. Laboratory sessions provide practical experience in advanced clinical procedures in neurodiagnostics and sleep science.

Name: NDSS 3405 - Neurodiagnostics and Sleep Science Practicum
Subject: NDSS
Description: Sleep disorders center and clinical neurophysiology laboratory clinical experience.

Name: NDSS 3900 - Undergraduate Research
Subject: NDSS
Description: Enables majors to initiate research projects in their respective fields of interests. The student’s work assignments are designed by the student and faculty member who oversee the project of study.  Credit hours are determined prior to enrollment and are based on the particular project undertaken.

Name: NDSS 4101 - Principles and Practice of Healthcare Education
Subject: NDSS
Description: Provides a foundation in the principles and practice of healthcare education. Topics include: the educational process, learner characteristics, and teaching and learning theories, techniques and strategies.

Name: NDSS 4104 - Advanced Physiological Monitoring and Data Acquisition
Subject: NDSS
Description: Explores the advanced clinical procedures performed in clinical neurophysiology laboratories and operating rooms. Topics include: nerve conduction velocity testing, autonomic testing, electronystagmography, visual, brainstem, auditory and somatosensory evoked potentials intraoperative neurophysiologic monitoring and maintenance. Laboratory sessions provide practical experience in neurophysiologic monitoring techniques.

Name: NDSS 4107 - Neurodiagnostics and Sleep Science Capstone
Subject: NDSS
Description: Students complete a project and presentation culminating from the undergraduate course of study. Project topics provide students the opportunity to summarize, evaluate, and integrate knowledge gained throughout the undergraduate major.

Name: NDSS 4201 - Information Technology and Analytics in Neurodiagnostics and Sleep Science
Subject: NDSS
Description: Focuses on information technology and analytics used specifically in neurodiagnostics and sleep science, including storage records, acquiring software requirements, and record transmission. The requirements and analytics of interoperative monitoring, long-term monitoring, epilepsy monitoring, WADA testing, and long-term Polysomnography acquisition, storage, sharing, and accreditation guidelines are examined.

Name: NDSS 4406 - Neurodiagnostics and Sleep Science Internship
Subject: NDSS
Description: Sleep and clinical neurophysiology laboratory educational/management internship with mentoring component.

Name: NURS 2100 - General Nutrition
Subject: NURS
Description: A solid knowledge base of general nutrition viewed from a life cycle perspective. Exploration of behavioral aspects and scientific concepts related to nutrition. Open to Pre-nursing majors, sophomore standing.

Name: NURS 2200 - Human Growth and Development
Subject: NURS
Description: Study of the developing person through the lifespan by examining the relationship of selected environmental and social factors to human growth and development. Consideration of the meaning of health and illness to the individual, the family, and the community within the context of life as a continuing, dynamic process from conception through death.
Restrictions: Pre-Nursing major; and Sophomore, Junior, or Senior standing.

Name: NURS 3102 - Introduction to Nursing Science
Subject: NURS
Description: An introduction to the theoretical and scientific basis of nursing practice, including an overview of the profession and examination of major concepts, theories, and models.

Name: NURS 3105 - Concepts of Professional Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: Concepts and standards fundamental to professional nursing practice. Explores the unique role of nursing in the healthcare system.

Name: NURS 3107 - Pathophysiology: Clinical Concepts of Illness and Disease
Subject: NURS
Description: Conceptual basis of alterations in physiological processes that disrupt or impair health and the body’s response to illness and disease. Building on knowledge obtained in previous courses in the biological and social sciences, this course provides a foundation for building critical thinking skills in the differentiation of disease and illness.

Name: NURS 3108 - Health Assessment and Application
Subject: NURS
Description: Evaluation of human function using interview and physical examination data within a framework for clinical decision making. Competencies necessary for holistic health assessment across the lifespan.

Name: NURS 3205 - Pharmacology in Health and Illness
Subject: NURS
Description: Presentation of the theoretical base for the safe and therapeutic use of drugs. Examination of Pharmacologic agents commonly used in health and illness and the standards and societal controls of drugs are explored.

Name: NURS 3230 - Illness and Disease Management
Subject: NURS
Description: Focus on health promotion strategies and nursing interventions appropriate for planning care of adult clients with basic pathophysiological alterations.

Name: NURS 3250 - Nursing Care of the Childbearing Family
Subject: NURS
Description: Foundations of nursing care of families during the childbearing year. Emphasis on the nurse’s role in health assessment, health promotion and promotion of adaptive processes of the individual and family during pregnancy, birth, transition to parenthood, and the newborn period, including alterations in health status.

Name: NURS 3260 - Nursing Care of Children
Subject: NURS
Description: Foundations of nursing care of children and families during the childrearing years. Emphasis on the nurse’s role in health assessment, health promotion and promotion of adaptive processes of the child and family during childhood from infancy to adolescence, including alterations in health status.

Name: NURS 3425 - Practicum in Concepts of Professional Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: This clinical course introduces the application of concepts, skills and values fundamental to professional nursing practice.

Name: NURS 3430 - Practicum Illness and Disease Management
Subject: NURS
Description: Clinical practice in healthcare settings that correlates with theoretical content related to basic pathophysiological alterations. Students will provide care in diverse clinical settings to develop psychomotor sills and apply knowledge in making clinical decisions.

Name: NURS 3440 - Practicum in Nursing Care of Children and the Childbearing Family
Subject: NURS
Description: Development of competencies essential for the nursing care of families during the childbearing and childrearing years. A variety of clinical experiences are provided, including community-based care, patient education, and in-patient care, with an emphasis on family-centered nursing practice.

Name: NURS 3700 - Creating and Sustaining Change in Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: Introduces students to the use of outcomes data to assess the need for change, allows students to explore state and national databases to evaluate organizational quality outcomes, provides an overview of nursing and change theories to guide the process of change, and introduce methods of overcoming resistance to change. Students identify a topic, develop a PICOT question, conduct a review of the literature, and initiate a plan for implementing a small test of change, research, quality improvement, or health promotion project. Topics, question, literature review, and plan framework must be approved by course faculty.
Restrictions: Admission to Nursing major and Nursing honors program, and permission of the instructor.

Name: NURS 3895 - Independent Study in Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: Directed individual study in a selected aspect of nursing which is explored in greater depth than included in the planned curriculum. No more than six hours in NURS 3895 may be counted toward degree requirements.

Name: NURS 4000 - Topics in Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: Critical examination of selected current topics in nursing.

Name: NURS 4090 - International Comparative Health Systems
Subject: NURS
Description: A study tour to explore the cultural, social, and healthcare systems outside the United States. Participants visit a variety of healthcare sites and attend presentations by practitioners and educators. They will have opportunities to interact with people from the host countries and visit a variety of cultural and historic sites.

Name: NURS 4100 - Nursing Care of the Aging Adult
Subject: NURS
Description: Examination of the processes of aging. Study of the nursing care for healthy, aging adults; frail, aging adults; institutionalized, aging adults; and dying, aging adults.
Restrictions: Senior standing in the Nursing Program.

Name: NURS 4120 - Psychiatric Mental Health Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: The foundation of Psychiatric Mental Health Nursing with emphasis on biopsychosocial content in the understanding and care of acute and chronic and chemically dependent clients.

Name: NURS 4130 - Complex Illness and Disease Management
Subject: NURS
Description: Illness and disease management of adult patients with complex pathophysiological alterations. Focus is on care management of clients with complex and pathophysiological health needs.

Name: NURS 4203 - Leadership and Informatics for Nursing Practice
Subject: NURS
Description: Introduction to leadership focusing on healthcare systems and the nurse’s role. Explore external and internal forces that affect the work environment and how to influence those forces. Discuss the work environment that best motivates people and creates an atmosphere that inspires, instills confidence and sustains individuals. Incorporate understanding of self to enhance beginning leadership.

Name: NURS 4240 - Population Focused Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: Examination and analysis of concepts and theories related to care of populations from a perspective of social justice. Focuses on health indicators and risk reduction in diverse groups across the lifespan and development of community partnerships within healthcare systems.

Name: NURS 4420 - Practicum in Psychiatric Mental Health Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: Development of competencies necessary for the practice of psychiatric mental health nursing. Emphasis is on the use of self in relationships, psychiatric nursing assessment, nursing interventions with clients and working as a member of the healthcare team. A variety of clinical settings are used.

Name: NURS 4430 - Practicum in Complex Illness and Disease Management
Subject: NURS
Description: Clinical practice in healthcare settings that correlate with theoretical content related to complex pathophysiological alterations. Students provide care in diverse clinical settings to continue to develop psychomotor skills and apply knowledge for clinical decision-making and reasoning.

Name: NURS 4440 - Practicum in Population Focused Nursing
Subject: NURS
Description: Development of competencies related to care of diverse populations.  Clinical experiences occur in a variety of communities and agencies that provide opportunities for interdisciplinary experiences.

Name: NURS 4450 - Design and Coordination of Care
Subject: NURS
Description: Clinical application of knowledge and skills in the design, management, and coordination of care for clients in a variety of healthcare settings.  Precepted clinical experience with written clinical decision making projects.

Name: NURS 4600 - Professional Nursing: Trends, Issues, and Licensure
Subject: NURS
Description: Current trends and issues that impact a variety of aspects of the nursing profession. Analysis of professional nursing practice in relation to current trends and issues. Required components for professional licensure in nursing, including preparation for the NCLEX-RN exam. Strategies for role transition from nursing student to professional nurse.

Name: NURS 4900 - Research in Nursing Practice
Subject: NURS
Description: Exploration of research methodologies relative to nursing practice, with emphasis on research utilization and evidence-based practice.

Name: NURN 3103 - Concepts of Professional Nursing Science
Subject: NURN
Description: Introduces professional nursing with emphasis on theoretical, ethical, and legal models guiding practice.
Restrictions: Admission to the RN-BSN Program or permission of instructor.

Name: NURN 3104 - Issues in Cultural Health
Subject: NURN
Description: Exploration of concepts and models of cultural health. Analysis of current issues related to culture and healthcare and the impact on provision of nursing care.
Restrictions: Admission to the RN-BSN Program or permission of instructor.

Name: NURN 3108 - Health Assessment for Nurses
Subject: NURN
Description: Evaluation of human function using interview and physical examination data within a framework for clinical decision making. Competencies necessary for holistic health assessment across the lifespan.
Restrictions: Admission to the RN-BSN Program or permission of instructor.

Name: NURN 3108L - Health Assessment Lab
Subject: NURN
Description: Evaluation of human function using interview and physical examination data within a framework for clinical decision making. Competencies necessary for holistic health assessment across the lifespan.

Name: NURN 4100 - Aging and Health
Subject: NURN
Description: Examination of physiological process of aging as a normal life experience. Study of psychological, nutritional, and general health issues designed to facilitate high-level wellness.
Restrictions: Admission to the RN-BSN Program or permission of instructor.

Name: NURN 4192 - Enhancing Clinical Judgment
Subject: NURN
Description: Enhances student’s ability to make sound nursing clinical judgments. Students have the opportunity to  reflect on their own style of thinking,  examine the role of critical thinking in making clinical judgments,  learn strategies for enhancing critical thinking and clinical reasoning,  practice applying the strategies in a variety of case studies,  critically study their own clinical practice, and  benefit from learning via online group discussion with peers.
Restrictions: Admission to the RN-BSN Completion option or permission of instructor.

Name: NURN 4201 - Information Technology: Applications in Healthcare
Subject: NURN
Description: A study of the use of computers and information technology in healthcare. Emphasis is placed on development of the knowledge and competencies necessary for selective use of evaluation of informatics, computer technology and data management in healthcare.
Restrictions: Upper-division standing or permission of instructor.

Name: NURN 4203 - Leadership in Nursing Practice
Subject: NURN
Description: Exploration of societal and professional trends and issues affecting nursing and healthcare. Leadership strategies within the profession and practice of nursing. Analysis of care that supports effective utilization of the healthcare delivery system. Health system mediation and health system management is explored from a nursing intervention perspective.
Restrictions: Admission to the RN-BSN Program or permission of instructor.

Name: NURN 4440 - Community Health Nursing
Subject: NURN
Description: Development of competencies for the nursing care management of culturally diverse individuals, families, and populations within communities with emphasis on the nurse’s role in health promotion and maintenance. Particular focus on risk identification and reduction throughout the life span.

Name: NURN 4450 - Design and Coordination of Care
Subject: NURN
Description: Application of theory-based practice in a variety of settings with clients who have multiple healthcare needs. Emphases are on clinical judgment and decision-making, diagnostic reasoning, clinical ethics, collaboration and case management. Examination of nursing therapeutics within the structure of nursing process and nursing diagnosis.

Name: NURN 4900 - Research in Nursing Practice
Subject: NURN
Description: Exploration of the theoretical foundations of nursing with emphasis on research, theories, concepts and processes leading to their application in practice.
Restrictions: Admission to the RN-BSN Program or permission of instructor.

Name: OPER 3000 - Topics in Operations Management
Subject: OPER
Description: Topics from the areas of Operations Management.

Name: OPER 3100 - Operations Management
Subject: OPER
Description: Introduction to and development of the management functions in manufacturing and non-manufacturing organizations.  A systems approach to the organizational environment, the basic operating functions, the problems and decisions a manager encounters and solution techniques and models.  Computer applications are included where appropriate.
Restrictions: College of Business major, Junior or Senior standing

Name: OPER 3201 - Operations Planning and Control
Subject: OPER
Description: An in-depth study of production planning and control activities in an enterprise resource planning context. Topics covered include: forecasting, operations and capacity planning, master production scheduling, material requirements planning, production activity control, inventory management, and Just-in-Time inventory systems. The use of software to manage operations and the interactions between operations and other functional areas of a business will be emphasized.
Restrictions: Management Information Systems or Operations and Supply Chain Management major or minor, or permission of department.

Name: OPER 3203 - Decision Modeling and Analysis
Subject: OPER
Description: Analytical approach to understanding the management process and solving management problems with emphasis on model formulation, solution techniques, and interpretation of results.  Topics include:  techniques such as linear, integer, goal, and multi-objective programming; queuing theory and applications; decision support via Monte Carlo simulation; decision making under uncertainty and risk; decision trees; and multi-criteria decision making.  Microsoft Excel is the main analytical tool.
Restrictions: Business Analytics, Management Information Systems, or Operations and Supply Chain Management major or minor, or permission of department.

Name: OPER 3204 - Management of Service and Project Operations
Subject: OPER
Description: Examines both strategic and operational decision making in service management with emphasis on the latter. Topics include: service strategy, designing new services, assessing and improving service quality, improving the efficiency and effectiveness of service processes, service process design and service facility location, managing waiting lines, managing service projects, and the integration of technology into service operations.
Restrictions: Management Information Systems or Operations and Supply Chain Management major or minor, or permission of department.

Name: OPER 3206 - Quality Assurance and Management
Subject: OPER
Description: A study of management philosophy, practices and analytical processes implemented in quality planning and administration of products and services. Topics include: corporate culture, quality design, human factors and motivation, quality cost analyses and auditing, service quality, quality assurance, quality circles, and conformance to design.
Restrictions: Management Information Systems or Operations and Supply Chain Management major or minor, or permission of department.

Name: OPER 3208 - Supply Chain Management
Subject: OPER
Description: A study of supply chain management concerned with all of the activities performed from the initial raw materials to the ultimate consumption of the finished product.  Examines the major aspects of the supply chain: the product flows; the information flows; and the relationships among supply chain participants.  Topics include: supply chain information technologies, supply chain design, strategic alliances between supply chain participants, and supply chain initiatives.
Restrictions: Management Information Systems or Operations and Supply Chain Management major or minor, or permission of department.

Name: OPER 3400 - Operations and Supply Chain Management Internship
Subject: OPER
Description: Provides a meaningful work experience in the field of operations and/or supply chain management. Requires a minimum of 150 hours of supervised employment, 50 hours of work per credit hour. Students are responsible for securing internship and completing internship application and approval process prior to registering for the course. Internship must be approved by instructor. Application process and course registration must be completed prior to beginning internship. All proposals are subject to departmental approval. Students may not earn internship credit for work at a current employer. May be used to meet requirements of a major elective, up to a maximum of three credit hours.
Restrictions: Junior or Senior in good standing and department approval.  Cannot be taken for credit at the same time or following any other internship for credit.

Name: OPER 3500 - Operations and Supply Chain Management Cooperative Education Experience
Subject: OPER
Description: Enrollment in this course is required for the department’s cooperative education students during each semester they are working in a position.  Participating students pay a course registration fee for transcript notation.  Assignments must be arranged and approved in advance.  The Cooperative Education Program is only open to undergraduate students; graduate level students are encouraged to contact their academic departments to inquire about academic or industrial internship options for credit.  For more information, contact the University Career Center.
Restrictions: Operations and Supply Chain Management major.

Name: OPER 3800 - Directed Study
Subject: OPER
Description: Enrollment granted only by permission of the faculty with whom the work will be performed. The student’s work assignments will be designed by the student and faculty member who will oversee the project of study. The credit hours will be determined prior to enrollment and will be based on the particular project undertaken.
Restrictions: Junior or Senior standing; and permission of department.

Name: OPRS 3111 - Operations Research: Deterministic Models
Subject: OPRS
Description: Linear, integer and dynamic programming, the simplex method, networks, PERT and CPM techniques, game theory, and applications.

Name: OPRS 3113 - Operations Research: Probabilistic Models
Subject: OPRS
Description: Queuing models, inventory models, simulation, markov chains, decision analysis, game theory and probabilistic dynamic programming.

Name: OPRS 4113 - Game Theory
Subject: OPRS
Description: The theory of zero-sum matrix games, mini-max theorem, optimal strategies, symmetric games, economic models, infinite, separable, polynomial, multi-stage, general-sum and in-person games. A project is required of all graduate students.

Name: OPRS 4114 - Dynamic Programming
Subject: OPRS
Description: The identification of dynamic programming problems and their solution in terms of recurrence relations. Elementary path problems, resource allocation, shortest path, traveling salesmen problem, discrete-time optimal control, replacement models, and inventory systems. A project is required of all graduate students.

Name: PHIL 1502 - Global Arts/Humanities: Global and Comparative Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: This Global Theme course uses the methods and insights of the arts and humanities to explore the central question of what it means to be a citizen of the world. Through the study of one or more different peoples, societies or cultures across the globe, students will be able to better understand themselves as part of a complex, interconnected world. This course introduces students to philosophical reflection and activity as sets of practices spanning a variety of historical, cultural, and national contexts. Students may explore questions such as how different cultures and communities understand and experience knowledge, ethics, injustice, death, humor, the self, or the good life.

Name: PHIL 1512 - Local Arts/Humanities: Philosophy and Community
Subject: PHIL
Description: This Local Theme course uses the methods and insights of the arts and humanities to explore the central question of what it means to be a member of a “local” community. Through the study of the experiences of different peoples, societies, cultural traditions, and modes of expression in communities at the city, regional, or national level students will be able to better understand the complexity and diversity of the society in which we live. This course involves philosophical reflection on the processes and structures that shape how people live, struggle, and make progress together in a set of overlapping communities. Students may explore questions such as how different cultures and communities understand and experience love and sex, healthcare, technology, democracy, or freedom.

Name: PHIL 2100 - Critical Thinking in Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: Fundamental skills of clear thinking that help students reason better during communication, problem-solving, and design, particularly as these integrate scientific/engineering efforts with social needs and values. Focuses on clarifying goals, identifying constraints, and generating and evaluating ideas or solutions.
Restrictions: Students are ineligible to take this course if credit has already been received for PHIL 1106.

Name: PHIL 2105 - Deductive Logic
Subject: PHIL
Description: Principles of deductive logic, both classical and symbolic, with emphasis on the use of formal logic in analysis of ordinary language discourse.

Name: PHIL 2220 - Healthcare Ethics
Subject: PHIL
Description: Major ethical dilemmas within medical science and biology are examined to assist students to identify, analyze, and decide ethical issues in such a way that they can defend their positions to themselves and others. Issues include reproductive and genetic technology, death and dying, patient rights, and justice in distribution of healthcare benefits and burdens.

Name: PHIL 3009 - Major Figure in Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: An investigation into the thoughts and writings of a major figure in philosophy with special emphasis on primary sources. Included may be Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, Kant, Marx, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Quine, Davidson, Rawls, and others as indicated by departmental needs and interests.

Name: PHIL 3019 - Topics in History/Genealogy
Subject: PHIL
Description: Specific topics in the history/genealogy of philosophy.

Name: PHIL 3039 - Topics in Ethics/Aesthetics
Subject: PHIL
Description: Specific topics of Ethics/Aesthetics.

Name: PHIL 3059 - Topics in Knowledge/Language
Subject: PHIL
Description: Specific topics in Knowledge/Language.

Name: PHIL 3079 - Topics in Identity/Society
Subject: PHIL
Description: Specific topics in Identity/Society.

Name: PHIL 3201 - Ancient Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: Western intellectual and philosophic thought from the early Greeks to the post Aristotelian period, often with an eye to issues in contemporary philosophy. Readings from the pre Socratics, Plato, Aristotle, Epicureans, Stoics, Skeptics, and Neoplatonists.

Name: PHIL 3202 - Modern Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: Modern philosophic and scientific thought from Descartes to Kant. Readings selected from representative works in the 17th and 18th centuries.

Name: PHIL 3203 - Nineteenth-Century Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: Examination of some central problems, issues, and methodologies of Nineteenth-Century Philosophy, including from some more contemporary perspectives, such as feminism. Examination may include: German Idealism , Early Existentialism , Early Phenomenology , Social Philosophy , and American Philosophy .

Name: PHIL 3204 - Twentieth-Century Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: Examination of some central problems, issues, and methodologies of Twentieth-Century Philosophy. Examination may include: pragmatism, phenomenology, logical analysis, existentialism, ordinary language philosophy, critical theory, hermeneutics, structuralism, or post-structuralism.

Name: PHIL 3211 - Latin American Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: This course is a survey of central texts and movements within Latin American philosophy. Themes of the course include pre-colonial Indigenous metaphysics, political philosophy within conquest-era debates and nation-building projects, Afro-Latin American movements, Latin American feminist philosophy, and philosophical lessons from decolonial and anti-imperial projects across Latin America.

Name: PHIL 3212 - American Philosophy
Subject: PHIL
Description: Analyzes the question of what constitutes American Philosophy, examining the interaction between America and philosophy and exploring some of the characteristics that may help contribute to the characterization of American Philosophy including: individualism, community, practicality, fallibility, and meliorism. Critically examines the narrative of American philosophy, focusing on pragmatism, America’s distinctive contribution to philosophy, and assesses the role that American philosophy has, can, and should play concerning social and cultural issues in America.

Name: PHIL 3213 - Existentialism
Subject: PHIL
Description: Existentialist tradition in philosophy and literature including such issues as: authenticity, absurdity and the meaning of life, freedom and morality, anguish, death, and atheism.

Name: PHIL 3221 - Ethical Theory
Subject: PHIL
Description: Selective examination of major normative and metaethical theories that undergird our practical judgments about morally right actions and virtuous persons. Normative theories studied may include virtue ethics, deontology, consequentialism, and representative feminist theories. Metaethical theories studied may include cognitivism, expressivism, realism, and error theory.

Name: PHIL 3222 - Environmental Ethics
Subject: PHIL
